column24:
· You light a bonfire on the ground within a range
that you can see. Until the spell ends, this magical bonfire fills a 5-foot cubic space. When you cast this
spell, each creature in the bonfire's space must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 1d8 points of damage. A creature must also make this
saving throw when it enters the bonfire's space for the
first time in a turn or when it ends its turn in the bonfire's space. · The bonfire can ignite flammable objects in the area that are not being worn or carried. · At 5th level, the damage of
this spell increases by 1d8 (to 2d8). At 11th level, add 1d8 (to 3d8), and at 17th level, add 1d8 (to 4d8).

M Materials: A bit of phosphorus or glow elm
Spell Description:
· You
create four torch-sized sources of light within range. For the duration of the spell, the sources appear as torches, lanterns, or orbs of light that float in midair. You can also combine the
four sources into a single, indistinct shadow of a Medium humanoid. Whichever method you choose, each source casts dim light in a 10-foot
radius.
· You can use a bonus action on your turn to move these lights up to 60 feet within range. Each light must be within 20 feet
of the other, and lights that leave range are immediately extinguished.
Name: Dancing Lights

Duration:
· You whisper to the spirits of nature, creating one of the following
effects:
√ You create a small, harmless sensory effect that predicts the weather conditions in your location for the next 24 hours. The
effect can manifest as a golden ball for a clear sky, a cloud for a rainy day, snowflakes for a snowy day, and so on. This
effect lasts for 1 round. √ You can instantly cause a flower to bloom, a seed to
break its shell, or a leaf to sprout. √You create a small, harmless, immediate sensory effect, such as falling leaves, a breeze,
the movement of a small animal, or the faint
scent of a skunk. This effect operates only in a 5-foot cube. √You can instantly light or extinguish a candle, a torch,
or a small campfire.

each ray.

Name: Player's Handbook

Spell Description:
· You cause a creature you can see within range to freeze.
The target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed
save, the target takes 1d6 points of cold damage and gains disadvantage on the next weapon attack roll made before the
end of its next turn. · When you reach 5th level, the damage of this spell increases by 1d6 (to 2d6).
At 11th level, add another 1d6 (to 3d6), and at 17th level, add another 1d6 (to 4d6).
Name: Frostbite

Material Content: A melee weapon worth at least 1

Level:
· As part of casting this spell, you must make a melee attack with your weapon against a creature within 5
feet. If the attack hits, the target is affected by the attack normally, and the
emerald flame jumps from the target to another creature within 5 feet of it. The second creature takes points of fire
damage equal to your spellcasting ability modifier. The damage of this spell increases as you level. At 5th level, this melee
attack deals an extra 1d8 fire damage, and the second target takes 1d8 + your spellcasting ability modifier. Both damage
dice increase by 1d8 at 11th
level (2d8 and 2d8), and by another 1d8 at 17th level (3d8 and 3d8).

Spell Description:
· At a point within range that you can see, the air is controlled
by you, forcing one of the following effects: ·
A Medium or smaller creature of your choice must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 5
feet away. · You can create a small burst of air, enough to move an object that is not being held or carried and weighs no
more than 5 pounds. The object is pushed 10 feet away
from you. The force created this way is not enough to cause damage. · You manipulate the air to create harmless sensory
sensations, such as rustling leaves, closing shutters, or your clothing
fluttering in the breeze.
Name: Dancing Wind

V Verbal:
· You cause a creature within range that you can see to temporarily swarm with
mites, fleas, and other parasites. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take 1d6 points of poison damage
and move 5 feet in a random direction, as long as it can move and has a speed of at least 5 feet. Roll 1d4 to determine
direction: 1, north; 2, south;
3, east; 4, west. This movement does not provide attacks of opportunity, and if movement in that direction is blocked, the
target does not move. · The damage of this spell increases by 1d6 points
at 5th level (2d6), 11th level (3d6), and 17th level (4d6).

Material Content: One firefly or a patch of phosphorescent moss
Spell Description:
· You
touch an object no larger than 10 feet in any direction. Until the spell ends, the object shines brightly in a 20-foot radius and
dimly in an additional 20 feet. The color of the light is yours, and the object's light is blocked if it is completely
obscured by something opaque. The spell ends if you cast it again or use an action to dismiss it. · If you target an object held
or worn by a hostile creature, that creature must make a Dexterity saving throw to try to
shake off the spell's effects.
Name: Light

Range:
· You create a whip of lightning energy that strikes a creature you can see within 15 feet. The target must
make a Strength saving throw or be pulled 10 feet closer to you in a
straight line. ft. If the target is within 5 feet of you after you pull in, it takes 1d8 points of lightning damage. · When you reach
5th level, the damage of this spell increases by 1d8 (to 2d8). At 11th level, add another 1d8 (to 3d8), and at
17th level, add another 1d8 (to 4d8).

Duration:
· A floating ghostly hand appears at a point you specify within range.
The ghostly hand persists until the spell ends or until you dismiss the spell as an action. If the
ghostly hand is more than 30 feet away from you or if you cast the spell again, the existing ghostly hand disappears. · You
can use your actions to control the ghost hand, and use it to perform one action: you can manipulate an object, open an
unlocked door or container, place an object in or take an
object out of a container, or pour the contents of a vial. You can move the ghost hand up to 30 feet each time you use it.
· The ghost hand can't attack, or activate
magic items or carry more than 10 pounds of matter.
Name: Mage Hand

Duration:
· You touch one to three small stones, infusing them with
magical power. You or another person can make a ranged spell attack by throwing one of the small stones, either unarmed or
with a sling. If thrown unarmed, its range is 60 feet. If someone other than you attacks with a small rock, the attacker adds
your spellcasting ability modifier to his or her attack roll, not the
attacker's. If the target hits, the target takes 1d6 points of bludgeoning damage equal to your spellcasting ability
modifier. Whether the target hits or not, the magic on the rock is lost.
If you cast this spell again, the effect of the spell on the affected rock ends earlier than it did when it was cast previously.

Level:
·This spell repairs a tear or crack in an object you touch, such as a broken chain, a key that's broken
in two, a torn cloak, a leaking wineskin, and so on. As long as the tear or crack is no more than 1 foot in any direction, you
can repair it without leaving a trace. ·This spell physically repairs a magic item or construct but does not restore the magic of such an item.

Spell Description:
· You point your finger at a creature
within range and whisper a message. The target (and only the target) hears the message and can reply in a whisper that
only you
can hear. · You can cast this spell through solid objects, but you must be familiar with the target and know it is behind the
barrier. Magical silence, 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood can block the spell.
The spell does not need to travel in a straight line; it can pass around corners and through
holes.
Name: Message

Spell Name:
· You pierce the mind of a visible creature within range with a spike of psionics. The target must make an
Intelligence saving throw or take 1d6 points of psychic damage, and on
your next saving throw before the end of your turn, subtract 1d4 from the result. · The damage of this spell increases by
1d6 at certain levels: 5th level (2d6), 11th level (3d6), 17th level (4d6).

column24:
· You
create an image of a sound or object within range that lasts until the spell's duration ends. You can also use an action to
dismiss the illusion or cast
the spell again to end it. If you create a sound, it can be as loud as a whisper or a high scream. It can be your voice or
anyone else's, or it can be the roar of a lion, the sound of a drum, or any other sound you specify. The sound does not
diminish over its duration, or you can create several discrete sounds at different
times before the spell ends. If you create an image of an object (such as a chair, a footprint in the mud, a small box), the
object must be no larger than a 5-foot cube. The image has no sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect. Since
images can be penetrated by any object, physical interaction with them reveals their true
nature as illusions. A creature that uses its action to investigate the sound or image must make an Intelligence (Investigation)
check against the spell's save DC to determine that it is an illusion. Illusions appear blurry to creatures that see
through them.

Name: Transformation
column23:
·
You choose a pile of dirt or a piece of rock that you can see within range and that fills a 5-foot cube.
You can transform it in one of the following ways: · If you point to a patch of loose soil, you can immediately dig it up,
causing it to move along the surface and be
transported up to 5 feet away. The force of this movement is not enough to cause damage. · You cause the dirt or rock to
change
shape and/or color, to write words, draw patterns, or carve patterns. This transformation lasts for 1 hour. · If the dirt or
rock you specify is on the surface, you can cause it to become difficult terrain.
Alternatively, you can cause an area of the surface that is already difficult terrain to become normal terrain. This
transformation lasts for 1 hour. · If you cast this spell multiple times, you can have up to
two non-immediate effects active at the same time, and you can dismiss any of these effects as an action.

Range:

harm you or your equipment. The flame provides bright light in a 10-foot radius around it, and dim light up to 10 feet
beyond that radius. The spell ends when you cast it again or dispel it as an action. ·Alternatively, you can attack with
the fire, which ends the spell. When you cast this spell, you can hurl the flame at a creature within 30 feet of you and
make a ranged spell attack against it that deals 1d8 points of fire damage. You can also do this as an action in a subsequent

movement is insufficient to cause damage. · You cause the water to take on simple shapes
and move as you wish. This change lasts for 1 hour. · You change the color or clarity of the water. The

freeze the water, as long as no living creatures are within it. The water thaws in 1 hour. If you cast this spell more than

With multiple casts of this spell, you can maintain up to three effects
that last for 1 minute at a time. You can also dispel one of these effects as an action.

spirit of the familiar based on the following: bat, cat, crab, frog (toad), hawk, lizard, octopus, owl, poisonous snake, fish

statistics of the chosen creature, but is a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) rather than a beast. Your familiar can act
independently, but will follow your commands at all times. In combat, it rolls initiative for itself and acts on
its turn. A familiar cannot attack, but it can perform other actions normally. A familiar disappears when it reaches 0 hit
points, leaving no physical remains. It reappears when you recast
the spell. You can communicate with your familiar telepathically while it is within 100 feet of you. In addition, you can
use
an action to switch your sight and hearing to your familiar's senses until your next turn. During this time, you also gain
the familiar's special senses, while your own senses are equivalent to being deafened and blinded. You can use an
action to temporarily dismiss your familiar. It will then enter a small plane
and wait for you to summon it again. Alternatively, you can choose to dismiss it permanently. When temporarily
dismissed, you can use an action to summon it to appear in any unoccupied space within 30 feet. ·You cannot have
more than one familiar at a time. If you cast this spell while already having a familiar, you may choose a new form for
your existing familiar (choose from the list
above). ·In addition, when you cast a spell with a casting range of reach, your familiar can deliver the spell for you, and
the effect is as if the spell was cast by the familiar. Your familiar must be within 100 feet of you, and it must be able to
use a reaction to deliver the spell. If the delivered spell requires an attack roll, your own attack modifier is used
for that roll.

Spell Description:
·This spell creates a

created and appears on the ground in

drop to 0, the spell ends. As a bonus action each of your turns, you can mentally command the servant to move up to 15 feet and
interact with an object. The servant can perform simple tasks that a human servant would do, such as fetching, cleaning, mending,
folding laundry, lighting fires, serving food,
and pouring wine. Once you give a command, the servant does its best to complete the task you commanded it to do, and then
waits for your next command. If you command the
servant to do a task that requires it to move 60 feet away from you, the spell ends.

Duration:
· You can read the thoughts of one
creature for the duration of the spell. You can do this while casting the spell or as an action during the duration. The creature
must be within 30 feet of you and visible to you, and you must concentrate on it. If the creature has an Intelligence of 3 or lower or
knows no languages, it is unaffected. You initially learn the
surface of the creature's thoughts, generally what it is thinking at the moment. You can use your action to delve deeper into a
creature's mind, or you can use your action to redirect the target of your mind reading. If you delve deeper, the target must make
a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you learn its reasoning (if any), its emotional state, and some of the major things on its
mind (such as its worries, loves, and hates). On a successful save, the spell ends. In either case, the target knows you are looking
into its thoughts. Unless you redirect your attention to another creature, it can use its action on its turn to make an Intelligence
check opposed by your Intelligence check; if the creature wins the
contest, the spell ends. Asking questions of the target can guide its thought process, making
this spell particularly effective in interrogation. You can also use this spell to detect thinking creatures that you cannot see. You
can do this as you cast the spell or as an action while the spell lasts. When you do this, you can search for thoughts within 30 feet.
This spell can penetrate most obstacles, but is blocked by 2 feet of stone, 2 inches of metal, or a thin layer of lead. You can't
detect creatures with an Intelligence of
3 or lower, or creatures that don't speak any language. · After detecting a creature in this way, you can read its thoughts as
described above for the duration of the spell. You don't even need to see the creature, but it must be within 30 feet of it.

Spell Name:
· You embed a message into an object within range that is spoken when the conditions are met.
Specify an object you can see that is not worn or carried by another creature. You can then use up to 10 minutes to deliver the
message, which can be no more than 25 words. Finally, you can set the event that triggers the spell to deliver the message. When
the event you specify occurs, the magic on the target object forms a mouth
that repeats the stored message in the same voice and volume as you. If the target you specify has a mouth or a mouth-like
structure (such as the mouth of a statue), the magic mouth is created in the place of the mouth structure, making it appear as if
the object's mouth is speaking. When you cast this spell, you can have the spell end immediately after delivering the message, or
you can have the spell continue and repeat the message each time it is triggered by the specified condition.
The trigger you choose can be as general or as specific as you want, but you can only set conditions based on visual or auditory
conditions within 30 feet of the target object. For example, you can command the magic mouth to speak the message when any
creature moves within 30 feet of the object, or when a silver bell rings within 30 feet of it.

Level:

and is restrained for the duration of the spell. · As an action, you can cause the hand to crush the restrained creature, which must

bludgeoning damage. On a successful save, it takes only half as much damage. · To escape the restraints, the restrained creature

to.

Spell Description:

can see within range. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw, taking 3d8 psychic damage on a failed save, or half as
much on a successful one. If the target fails its saving throw, you gain knowledge of the target's location until the spell ends,
as long as you are on the same plane. While you have this information, the target can no longer hide from you, and if it is
invisible, it does not benefit from that condition against you. · Upgraded spellcasting effects. When you cast this spell using a
spell slot of 3rd level or higher, increase the damage by 1d8 for each higher level slot used.

column38:
· Three illusory
copies of yourself appear at your location. Until the spell ends, the copies move with you and mimic your movements and
changes of position, making it impossible to track which one is your real
self. While the copies exist, you can use your action to dismiss the illusory copies. · For the duration of the spell, each time a
creature
targets you with an attack, roll a d20 to determine whether the attack hits one of the copies. If you have three copies, you
must roll a 6 or higher for the target's attack to hit one. If you have two copies, you must roll an 8 or higher. If
you have one copy, you must roll an 11 or higher. The copies' AC is equal to 10 + your Dexterity modifier. When a single attack
hits a copy, that copy is immediately destroyed. A copy is destroyed by only one attack that hits it, ignoring all
other damage and effects. The spell ends when all three copies are destroyed. This spell has no effect on a creature that
cannot see, that can rely on a sense other than sight (such as blindsight), or that can see illusions as if they were real.

Spell Name: teleporting to an unoccupied location you can see up to 30 feet away.

Spell Description:
· A 5-foot-radius, 40-foot-tall, column-shaped area centered on a point within range is bathed in a faint silvery light.
The column remains filled with dim light until the spell ends. ·
Creatures that enter the area for the first time in a turn or start their turn in the area are engulfed in ghostly flames and suffer
intense burning pain. The creature must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 2d10 points of radiant damage on a failed
save,
or half as much damage on a successful one. · A polymorphed creature has disadvantage on this saving throw, and if it fails it
immediately reverts to its original form, and
cannot change into another form until it leaves the light of the spell. · You can use an action on each of your turns
after casting this spell to move the radiance up to 60 feet in any direction. · Upgraded spellcasting effect. When casting this
spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, increase the damage by 1d10 for
each level higher than 2nd level you use the slot.
Name: Moonbeam

divination spells to reveal false information about the target. The target
can be a willing creature or an object that is not being worn or carried by another creature. When you cast this spell, you
choose one or two of the following effects. The effect lasts for the duration. If you cast this spell on the same creature or
object every day for 30 days and choose the same effect each time, the illusion persists until it is dispelled. False Aura: Detect
aura spells and magical effects (such as the spell detect magic) display different information about the target. You can make a
nonmagical object appear magical, a magical object appear nonmagical, or change an object's magical aura to appear to be of
a specific school of magic of your choice. When you cast this effect on an object, you cause this false magic to appear to any creature using the item.

Mask: Spells and magical effects that detect a creature's type (such as a paladin's divine sense or the triggering condition of a symbol spell)
now display different information. You choose a creature type, and other spells and magical effects will interpret the target creature as that
type or as belonging to that type's alignment.

·You designate a creature you can see within range and create an illusion rooted in its consciousness. The target must make an
Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, you create an illusory
object, creature, or other visible phenomenon of your choice, no larger than a 10-foot cube that can be perceived only by the target. This
creation persists until the spell ends. The spell has no effect on undead creatures and constructs. ·The illusion includes sound, temperature,
and other responsive factors, and is also only visible to the target. ·The target can use its action to make an Intelligence (Investigation) check
against the spell's save DC to examine the illusion. On a successful check,
the target realizes that the illusion is an illusion, and the spell ends. ·The target under the spell's influence assumes the illusion is real and
will rationalize any illogical interactions with the illusion. For example, a subject trying to walk across an illusory bridge across a ravine falls
off the bridge as soon as it takes its first step. If the target survives the fall, it still believes the bridge was real and may offer some alternative
explanation for its fall—perhaps a shove, a slip, or perhaps a strong wind blew it off. The target is convinced of the illusion's reality
and is even harmed by it. An illusion
that takes the form of a creature can attack the target. For example, an illusion that takes the form of fire, acid, or lava can burn the target. On
each of your turns, the illusion can deal 1d6 points of psychic damage to the target while it is in the illusion's damage area or within 5 feet of the
creature
it manifests. The target then feels the damage as if it were the type of creature the illusion manifested.

If the web is not anchored between two solid objects (such as a wall or tree) or straddles a floor, wall, or ceiling, the web you

saving throw. On a failed save, it is restrained in the
web until it leaves the web or breaks free. A creature restrained by a web can use an action to try to break free. The creature
must make a Strength check against the spell save DC to be freed on a successful check. The webs are flammable. Each

burning area
takes 2d4 points of fire damage as a result.

·This spell creates an undead servant. Designate the remains or body of a Medium
or Small humanoid within range and use this spell to infuse it with a foul, false life force, raising it as an undead
creature. If you choose bones, the target becomes a skeleton; if you choose a body, it becomes a zombie.
The specific game data of this creature is controlled by the DM. On any of your turns, you can use a bonus action to mentally
command any creature within 60 feet that you have summoned with this spell. (If you are summoning multiple creatures, you can
give them all or just some of them at once, but only with the same command.) You decide the actions and movements of the
summoned creatures on their next turns. Alternatively, you can give them general orders (such as guarding a room or hallway).
Creatures that do not receive your orders can only defend themselves against hostile creatures. Once given an order, the creature continues to follow it until 
· These controlled creatures obey your commands only for 24 hours. If you cast this spell again before the current 24-hour period ends,
your control over these creatures is extended by an additional 24 hours. This use of the spell only extends your control over up to four
creatures you created with this spell; it does not create new creatures.
· Higher-level spellcasting effects. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you raise two more undead creatures
or extend your control over two more undead creatures for each level higher than the 3rd level of the slot you used. You cannot raise
multiple undead creatures from the same skeleton or body.

·You roll a d20 at the end
of each of your turns during the spell's duration. If the result is 11 or greater, you vanish from your current plane and reappear on the
Ethereal Plane (if you are already on the Ethereal Plane, the spell fails and is expended). At the start of each of your turns and at the end
of the spell, if you are on the Ethereal Plane, you reappear in an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see within 10 feet of where
you disappeared. If there are no unoccupied spaces within range, you reappear in the nearest random
unoccupied space. You can dispel the spell as an action. ·When you are on the Ethereal Plane, you can hear and see your home plane,
but only within 60 feet, and everything is black and white. Other creatures can affect you or be affected by you only when they are on the
Ethereal Plane. Creatures not on the Ethereal Plane cannot sense you or communicate with you unless they have the ability to do
so.

Spell Name:
· When you cast this spell, you carve a rune that harms other creatures into a surface (such as a table,
floor, or wall) or into an object that can be closed to hide the rune (such as a book, scroll, or treasure chest). If you specify a surface,
the rune can cover an area up to 10 feet in diameter. If you specify an object, it must stay where it is. If the object is moved more than
10 feet from the location, the rune is destroyed and the spell ends without being triggered. Ward runes are nearly
invisible and require an Intelligence (Investigation) check at the spell's save DC to be discovered. You set the triggering
conditions for a ward rune when you cast the spell. Runes carved on surfaces typically trigger by touching or standing on the rune,
removing an object covering the rune, coming within a certain distance of the rune, or manipulating the object the rune is on. Runes
carved into objects typically trigger by opening the object, getting within a certain distance of the object, or seeing or reading the rune.
Once the rune is triggered, the spell ends.
You can further refine the triggering conditions, such as requiring the spell to be triggered only when certain conditions are met, or
requiring the triggering person to have certain physical characteristics (height, weight, etc.), a certain creature type (for example, to
affect only aberrations or drow), or a certain alignment. You can also exclude people with certain conditions from being able to trigger the rune, such as someone 
·When you create a rune, you can choose between an Explosive Rune and a
Spell Rune. ·Explosive Runes: When triggered, a rune explodes with magical energy in a 20-foot-radius sphere that spreads
around corners. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 5d8 acid, cold, fire, lightning,
or thunder damage (which you specified when you created the rune) on a failed save,
or half as much damage on a successful one. ·Spell Rune: You can cast a prepared spell of 3rd level or lower stored in the
rune you created. The stored spell must target a creature or an area, and it does not take effect immediately when cast in this
way. The stored spell is cast immediately when the rune is triggered. If the spell targets a target, the creature that triggered the
rune is targeted; if the spell affects an area, the area is centered on the creature; if the spell summons a hostile creature or
creates an object or trap of a harmful nature, the creation manifests wherever it can get close to the triggerer and attacks it. If
the spell requires
concentration, its effect lasts for its maximum duration. · Upgraded-level spellcasting effects. When casting this spell using a
spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage of a blast rune increases by 1d8 for each level above 3rd that the slot you use is
higher. If you create a spell rune, its reserve spells can be of the same level as the slot you used to cast the
glyph of warding.

Spell Description:
·You create an
image of an object, creature, or other visible phenomenon no larger than a 20-foot cube. The image appears at a location you can see
within range and persists for the duration of the spell. It appears completely real and has corresponding sounds, smells, and
temperatures. You can't create heat or cold strong enough to cause harm, or sounds loud enough to cause thunder damage or
deafen creatures, or smells that sicken creatures (similar to the stench of troglodytes). · While you are within range of this illusion, you
can use your action to move the image to another location within range. As the image changes location, you can alter the image's
appearance to make it move more naturally. For example, if you create an image of a creature and move it, you can alter the image so
that it appears to be walking. Or you can have the image make different sounds at different times, or even have it engage in a conversation.

· Because the image cannot be touched, any physical interaction with it reveals its illusory nature. When a creature uses its action
to investigate the image, it can make an Intelligence (Investigation) check against your spell save DC to determine whether it sees
through the illusion. A creature that recognizes the illusion sees through the image, and the image's other sensory
effects appear faint and blurry to the creature. · Upgraded spellcasting effect. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th
level or higher, the spell lasts until it is dispelled and does not require your
concentration.

You enter a stone object or surface large enough to completely contain your body, causing yourself and any equipment you carry to
become one with the stone for the duration of the spell. You can enter the stone from a location you can touch while moving.
Thereafter, no nonmagical senses can see or detect your presence. · While fused with the stone, you cannot see what is happening
in the outside world, and you have disadvantage on any Wisdom (Perception) checks you make to hear outside sounds. While fused
with the stone, you are still aware of the passage of time and can cast spells on yourself. You
cannot move, but you can move out of the stone from where you entered, ending the spell. · Minor damage to the stone does not
harm you, but if the stone is partially destroyed or changes shape (to the point where it no longer fits inside you), it ejects you
from the stone and deals 6d6 points of bludgeoning damage to you. If the stone is completely destroyed (or its material changes), it
ejects you from the stone and deals 50 points of bludgeoning damage to you. When ejected from the stone, you are thrown to
the nearest unoccupied
space from where you first entered the stone, and fall prone.

brisk pace. When the spell ends, the steed slowly fades away, giving the rider 1 minute to dismount and end the

within range become thicker and more luxuriant. A creature that moves through the area must expend 4 feet of movement for every foot it moves. You can clear 
When you cast this spell in 8 hours, you can make the land fertile. You designate a point within the range of the spell, and

crop when harvested.
Name: Plant Growth

objects and creatures in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the cone must succeed on a Constitution saving throw, taking 6d6
points of force damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures that fail their saves are pulled
toward you 15 feet or pushed away from you 15 feet, depending on your choice when casting the spell. In
addition, unworn or uncarried objects that are completely within the cone are also pulled toward you or pushed away
15 feet. Upgraded spellcasting effect. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you increase the spell's
damage by 1d6 and increase the distance it is pushed or pulled by 5 feet for each slot level above 3rd.

Spell Description:
· You send a short
message of up to twenty-five words to a creature you know. The creature hears your message in its mind, recognizes you
as the sender (if it knows you), and can immediately send a message in the same manner. The target must have an
Intelligence score of at least 1 to understand your message. · Your message can span any distance, even across planes.
However, if the target is not on the same plane of existence as you, there is a 5% chance that the
short message will not reach it.
Name: Short Message

Casting Time: A pinch of dust and a few drops of water
V Verbal:
· You designate a point within
range and cause an area 40 feet in radius and 20 feet high to fall with freezing sleet and hail
until the spell ends. The area is heavily obscured, and all open fires in the area are extinguished. · The ground in the area is
covered with a slick layer of ice, turning it into difficult terrain. A creature entering the area for
the first time in a turn or starting its turn in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw or fall to the ground on a failed save.
· If a creature in the spell's area is concentrating, that creature must make a Constitution saving throw
against your spell save DC or its concentration is broken on a failed saving throw.

Spell Description:
· You designate
up to six creatures in a 40-foot cube within
range and warp the flow of time around them. Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw or be affected by the spell until
the spell ends. · The target's speed is halved and it takes a -2 penalty on AC and Dexterity saving throws, and it can't use
reactions. The creature can take either an action or a bonus action on its turn,
but not both. Regardless of any abilities or magic items the creature possesses, it can make only one melee or ranged attack
on its turn. · If the creature attempts to cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action, roll a d20. If the result is 11 or higher, the
creature's spell doesn't take effect until
its next turn, and the creature must then use an action to complete the spell. If it can't, its spell is wasted. · The target creature
can make another Wisdom saving throw at the end
of its turn. On a success, the spell ends its effect on it.
Name: Slow

V Verbal:
· You grant a corpse within range a small amount of life and intelligence,
allowing it to answer your questions. The corpse must still have a mouth and must not be undead. If the target corpse has been the target of this spell within 
· You can ask the corpse up to five questions before the spell ends. The corpse's knowledge is limited to what it knew in life,
including the language it spoke. Answers are usually short, cryptic, or repetitive, and it is not required to give you the correct
answer if you are hostile to the corpse or if the corpse considers you its enemy. This spell does not return the creature's soul to
its body, but only animates its spirit. As a result, the corpse cannot learn new information, understand anything that has happened
since its death, or speculate about future events.

Spell Description:
· You grant limited sentience and
animation to plants within 30 feet of you, enabling them to communicate with you and act on your commands. You can ask plants
about what happened in the area in the past day, learning about creatures
that have passed through, weather, and other conditions. · You can cause difficult terrain (such as brush) created by plant growth
in the area to become normal terrain for the duration of the spell. You can also turn normal terrain with
plants into difficult terrain (such as vines and branches that hinder pursuers from behind). Plants may also do other things for you
at the DM's discretion. Although this spell cannot make plants uproot
or move freely, they can move their branches, vines, and stems freely. If there is a plant creature in the spell's area, you can
communicate with it as if
you have a common language, but you have no magical power to influence its position. This spell allows plants created by
entangle to release a bound creature.
Name: Speak

School:

within 15 feet of you for the duration of the spell. If you are good or neutral, their ethereal forms resemble angels or fey (your choice).
If you
are evil, they take the form of fiends. When you cast this spell, you may choose any number of creatures within your field of vision
to be unaffected by the spell. A creature affected by the spell has its speed halved while in the area, and must make a Wisdom
saving throw the first time it enters the area in a turn or the first time it starts its turn in the area. On a failed saving throw, it takes
3d8 points of radiant damage (if you
are good or neutral) or 3d8 points of necrotic damage (if you are evil), or half as much damage on a successful one. Higher-level
spellcasting effects. When casting this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the spell's
damage increases by 1d8 points for each level higher than 3rd that the slot you use is.

Spell Description:
· You call upon the spirits of the dead to surround you for the duration of the spell. These spirits are intangible and
invulnerable. · Until the spell ends, all your attacks that hit creatures within 10 feet of you deal an extra 1d8 points of damage. The
damage type is radiant, necrotic, or frozen (choose when you cast the spell). Any creature so damaged cannot regain hit points until
the start
of your next turn. · In addition, at the start of any creature's turn that is within 10 feet of you and visible to you, you can reduce its
speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. · Upgraded spellcasting effect. When casting this spell
using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, increase the damage by 1d8 for every two levels above 3rd that the slot you use is higher.
Name: Spirit Shroud

ground you can see within range. You can create a wall up to 30 feet long, up to 10 feet high, and up to 1 foot thick. Or you
can create a circular wall up to 20 feet in diameter, up to 20 feet high, and up to 1 foot thick. The wall disappears when the spell ends. The area of 
Any ranged weapon attack that enters the space of the wall has disadvantage on attack rolls, and fire effects that pass
through the wall to their targets deal half as much fire damage. Spells that deal cold damage through the wall freeze the
portion they pass through (at least 5 feet square). Each 5-foot square frozen has AC 5 and 15 hit points. Reducing a frozen
area to 0 hit points destroys it. When a section is destroyed, water from the wall does not fill its place.

Level:
· A wall of strong wind rises from a point on the ground within the specified
casting range. You can create a wall of wind up to 50 feet long, up to 15 feet high, and up to 1 foot thick. You can shape the
wall freely, but it must form a continuous track
along the ground. The wall of wind lasts until the spell ends. · When the wall of wind appears, all creatures in the area of
the wall must make a Strength saving
throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 3d8 points of bludgeoning damage, or half as much damage on a successful
one. · Strong winds can block thick fog, smoke, and other gases. Small or smaller flying creatures or objects cannot fly
through a wind wall. Lightweight uncarried objects carried into a wind wall are blown upward. Arrows, bolts, and other
ordinary flying objects fired at targets behind the wall are blown upward and are
considered misses. (Boulders and similar flying objects thrown by giants or siege engines are not affected.) Creatures in
gaseous form cannot pass through a wind wall.

you. The creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be charmed by you for the duration. While a creature is

You can assign a new task to the creature when its previous task is complete, or when you decide to end its current task. If
the activity or task might harm the creature or is contrary to its normal activities and desires, the
creature can make another Wisdom saving throw to end the
effect. If you or an ally is engaged in combat with the creature, it has advantage on this saving throw. If the action you

Name: Sannasa's Guide to Everything

V Verbal:
·Specify several creatures within range that you can see and hear and force each to make a Wisdom saving throw. Targets
that cannot be charmed succeed on their saving throws, while those that fail their saving throws are affected by the spell's effects. Until
the spell ends, you can use a bonus action on each of your turns to point in a horizontal direction. Then, each target must move as far as
possible in that direction on its next turn, using all its movement. The target may take its actions before moving, and after completing the
movement it may make another Wisdom saving throw to end the effect. ·Each target cannot be forced to walk toward an obviously lethal
hazard, such as a
fire or pit, though it may provoke attacks of opportunity if it moves in the direction.

· The target of the spell cannot use reactions and must roll a d10 at the start of its turn to determine what the

Ritual: A drop of water and a pinch of dirt
Range:
· You control any single body of water until the spell ends,
in a 100-foot cube of your choice. When you cast this spell, you can choose one of the following effects. On each of your subsequent
turns, you can use an action to perform the same effect again or choose a different one. · Rising Flood: You cause the water level in
the area you control to rise by up to 20
feet. If the area has a shore, the water overflows the dry soil covered by the rising water. If the area you specify is part of a larger body of
water, you
instead create a 20-foot-high wave that sweeps from one side of the area to the other and breaks the surface of the water. Any Huge or
smaller vehicles caught in the wave are carried to the other side of the wave. All Huge or smaller vehicles have a 25% chance of capsizing.
The waves roll over again at the start of your next turn.
Part Water: You cause the water in the area to split and form a channel. The channel stretches from one end of the spell's area to the
other, with the divided water forming two walls on either side. The channel lasts until the spell ends or until you choose another effect.
When this effect ends, the channel slowly returns to its normal level over the next round.
Redirect Flow: You cause water in the area to flow in a direction of your choice. You can cause it to flow around obstacles, up walls, or
even in unlikely directions. Water in the area flows in the direction you direct it, but once it leaves the spell's area, it returns to the direction
of the terrain it was in. The water continues to flow in the direction you choose until the spell ends or until you choose another effect.
Whirlpool:
This effect requires the water to be at least 50 feet square and at least 25 feet deep. You create a whirlpool in the center of the area. Its
shape is 5 feet wide at the bottom and 50 feet wide at the top, and 25 feet high. Any creature or object in the water that is within 25 feet of
the vortex is pulled 10 feet toward it. An affected creature can make a Strength (Athletics) check against your spell DC to swim out of the
vortex's grip. Any creature that
enters a vortex for the first time in a round or starts its turn inside a vortex must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the
creature takes 2d8 points of bludgeoning damage and is pulled into the center of the vortex until the spell ends. On a successful save,
the creature takes half as much damage and is not pulled into the vortex. A creature pulled into the center of the vortex can use its action
to try to swim out of the vortex (as described
above), but it has disadvantage on Strength (Athletics) checks made at this time. An object takes 2d8 points of bludgeoning damage the
first time it enters a vortex in a round; this damage continues each round if the object remains in
the vortex.

Duration:

loyal, majestic mount. The mount appears in an unoccupied space within range, and takes the form of your choice: Griffon,

The mount has the attributes of the form you choose, but it is actually a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) rather than a normal

closer together. While you're atop this mount, any spells you cast that target only
yourself also affect the mount. ·When the mount reaches 0 hit points, it vanishes, leaving no material residue. You can also
dismiss the mount at any time as an action to make it disappear. Thereafter, each time you recast this spell,
summon the same mount at full hit points. ·While the mount is within 1 mile of you, you
can communicate with it telepathically. ·You can't have more than one mount with this spell at a time. You can release the mount
from the bond and make it vanish at any time as an action.

Name: 24 hours
English:
· You cause all natural terrain in a
150-foot cube within range to look, sound, and smell like another natural terrain. Thus, an open plain or road might appear to be a
swamp, or hills, chasms, and other difficult or even impassable terrain. A pond might be made to look like a meadow, a cliff a gentle
slope, or a ravine a wide, smooth road. The appearance of structures, equipment, or creatures that have been manipulated in the area
is not altered. · The tactile characteristics of the terrain are not altered, so creatures entering the area may
be able to see through the illusion. If the tactile difference is not obvious, a creature carefully investigating the illusion can attempt a
saving throw against the spell DC. Intelligence (Investigation) checks are required to expose the illusion. To a creature that sees through
the illusion, the illusion appears as a blurry image superimposed on the real terrain.

a material component of the spell. The box can hold up to 12 cubic

both
the box and the copy to return the box to the Ethereal Plane. After 60 days, the spell's effects have a cumulative 5% chance of
ending automatically each day. The spell's effects end if you cast the spell again, if the box's model is destroyed, or if you end
the spell as an action. If the spell ends while the box is on the Ethereal Plane, it is irretrievably lost.

column25:
· You name or describe a creature you are familiar with. As long as the creature is within 1,000 feet of you, you gain a sense
of its location. If the creature is moving, you also know the
direction it is moving. · This spell can locate a specific creature you know; or it can locate the nearest member of a specific
class of creatures (such as humans or unicorns), provided you have seen that class of creature at least once within 30 feet. If the

running water at least 10 feet wide stands between you and the creature being located, blocking the path between the two, the

V Verbal:
· A faintly glowing sphere of force encloses a Large or smaller creature or object within range. An unwilling creature must
make a Dexterity saving throw or be trapped within the sphere for the duration of the spell. ·Nothing—physical objects, energy, or
other spell effects—
can penetrate the barrier of the force field sphere to enter or exit it, but creatures can still breathe normally inside the sphere. The
sphere is immune to all damage, and creatures or objects inside the sphere cannot be harmed by attacks or effects from outside the
sphere, and creatures inside the sphere cannot cause damage to
objects outside the sphere. ·The sphere is weightless and its size is just right to contain the creatures or objects inside the sphere.
The trapped creatures can use their actions to push the walls of the sphere and roll the sphere at half the
creature's speed. In addition, the sphere can be picked up or moved by other creatures. ·Casting
Disintegrate on the sphere can destroy the sphere without harming anything inside the sphere. ·Additional note: The designer
explained that [Teleport] effects such as Anywhere Door and Thunder Step can enter and
exit the force field wall.

to avoid this effect. This spell has no effect on a polymorphed creature or one with 0 hit points. ·The changes caused by the spell last

extra damage. As long as the extra damage does not reduce the creature's normal form to 0 hit points, it does not fall unconscious
from the blow. · The
creature's actions are limited by its new form. It cannot speak, cast spells, or perform other actions that require the use of its hands
or speech. · The target's equipment merges with its new form,
but it cannot activate, use, wield, or otherwise benefit from its equipment.

A creature can choose to fail its saving throw. If it fails, it is restrained by the water ball and submerged. At the end of each of its turns,
the restrained creature can retry this saving throw, ending the spell's effect on itself if it
succeeds. The water ball can hold up to four Medium (or smaller) creatures, or one Large creature. If the water ball restrains more
than the maximum number of creatures, a random creature already restrained is excluded and falls
prone within 5 feet of the water ball. As an action, you can move the water ball in a straight line up to 30 feet. If it moves over a pit, cliff,
or similar feature, it falls safely until it is suspended 10 feet above the ground. All creatures restrained by the water ball are moved with
it. You can force a creature to make a saving throw by
hitting it with the water ball. When the spell ends, the water ball falls to the ground, extinguishing all normal fires within 30 feet of it. Any
creature restrained by the water ball becomes prone at the point of impact. The water then disappears.

column24:
· Objects come alive at your command. Designate up to ten nonmagical objects, not being held or worn, within range as targets
of the spell. A Medium target counts as two objects, a Large target counts as four objects, and a Huge target counts as eight objects.
You cannot animate objects larger than Huge. After casting this spell, each target is a creature you control until the spell ends
or until the creature's hit points drop to 0. You can use a bonus action to mentally command any creature within 500 feet that you
animate with this spell (if you are
controlling multiple creatures, your commands can be given to all or just some of them at once, but you can only use the same
command). You decide the actions and movements of the creatures you animate on their next turn. Alternatively, you can give a
general order (such as guarding a room or hallway). Creatures that do not receive your orders will only defend themselves against
hostile creatures. Once given an order,
the creature continues to follow the order until the task is completed. See Additional Information for properties of animated objects.
The AC, hit points, attacks, and Strength and Dexterity scores of an animated object are determined by its size. Its Constitution is 10,
its Intelligence and Wisdom are 3, and its Charisma is 1. Its speed is 30 feet, or if it lacks legs or similar structures, it can fly 30 feet and
can hover. If the object is fastened to a surface or larger object (such as a chain to a wall), its speed is 0. It has blindsight 30 feet, and is
blinded outside its range. When an animated object
reaches 0 hit points, it reverts to being a normal object, and takes all damage as an object. If you command the animated object to
attack, it can make one melee attack against a creature within 5 feet of it. It slams with a bludgeoning attack that deals bludgeoning
damage with an attack bonus
and damage based on its size. The DM may also decide that certain objects can deal slashing or piercing damage. Higher-level
spellcasting effects. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, you evoke two
more objects for each level above 5th that the slot you use.

· A shimmering barrier surrounds an area within
10 feet of you and moves
around you, blocking all creatures except undead and constructs. The shield lasts until the spell ends. · The shield prevents affected
creatures from passing
through or entering it, but affected creatures can use spells, ranged weapons, or reach weapons to attack the inside of the shield.
· If you force an affected
creature into the shield as you move, the spell ends.

S Posture:
·After using the 8 hours it takes to cast the spell to channel the magic
in a costly gem, you touch a Huge or smaller beast or plant as the target of the spell. The target must have no Intelligence score or an
Intelligence score of 3 or less. Upon receiving the spell, its Intelligence becomes 10, and it learns to speak a language you know. If the
target is a plant, it gains the ability to move using branches, roots, vines, tendrils,
or similar parts, and gains humanlike senses. The DM determines the statistics for the enlightened plant; see the enlightened shrub
and enlightened tree in the Monster Manual for examples. ·The enlightened plant or beast remains under your charm for 30 days, or
until you or your allies do
something to harm it. After the charm ends, the enlightened creature becomes friendly to you based on how you treat it.

Material Content: An eggshell and a snakeskin glove
Spell Description:
· You create a
giant, shimmering hand in an unoccupied space you can see within range. The hand persists for the duration of the spell and moves
at your command, mimicking the movements of your hand. · Treat the hand as a Large object with an AC of
20 and hit points equal to your maximum hit points. The spell ends prematurely if it reaches 0 hit points. Its Strength is 26 (+8) and its
Dexterity is 10 (+0). The hand does not occupy the space it occupies. · When you cast this spell, you can
move the hand up to 60 feet away and cause one of the following effects. You can also complete this effect as a bonus action on your
subsequent turn. · Clenched Fist: The
hand casts 5 Strike a creature or object within 5 feet of the giant hand. Make a melee spell attack using your own game data that deals
4d8 points of force damage on a hit. Forceful Hand: The giant hand
attempts to push a creature within 5 feet of it. Oppose the giant hand's Strength check with the target's Strength (Athletics) check. If
the target is Medium or smaller, your check has advantage. If you win the opposition, the target is pushed a number of feet away
equal to 5 plus five times your spellcasting ability modifier. The giant hand moves with the target, staying 5 feet away from it.
Grasping Hand: The giant hand
attempts to grapple a Huge or smaller creature within 5 feet of it. The grapple calculation uses the giant hand's Strength score. If the
target is Medium or smaller, your check has advantage. While the giant hand is grappling the target, you can use a bonus action to
command the giant hand to squeeze the target, dealing 2d6 points of bludgeoning damage to the target + your spellcasting ability
modifier.
·Interposing Hand: A giant hand blocks you from a creature of your choice until you give it another command. The hand moves to
stay between you and the target, giving you half cover over the target. If the target's Strength is less than or equal to the hand's, it
cannot pass through the hand's blockade. If its Strength is higher than the hand's, the target can pass through the hand's space, but
the space must be considered difficult terrain by the
target. ·Upgraded spellcasting effect. When casting this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage of the diamond fist
increases by 2d8 and the damage of the grab palm increases by 2d6 for each level higher than the 5th level of the slot you use.

Name: Contagion
column25:
· Your touch
carries disease. You make a melee spell attack against a creature within reach. On a hit, you choose to give that creature one of
the diseases described below. · The touched creature must make a Constitution saving throw at the
end of each of its turns. After three failed saving throws, the disease effect lasts until the spell ends, and the creature no longer
makes a corresponding Constitution saving throw. After three successful saving throws, the creature recovers from the disease
and the spell ends. ·Since the spell
inflicts a natural disease on the target, any effect that removes or improves the condition also affects the affected creature.
·Blinding
Sickness: Pain grips the afflicted creature's mind, and the afflicted creature's eyes turn milky white. The afflicted creature has
disadvantage on Wisdom checks and Wisdom saving throws, and
suffers the blinded condition. ·Filth Fever: A severe fever breaks out in the afflicted creature's body. The afflicted creature has
disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength
saving throws, and on Strength-based attack rolls. ·Flesh Rot: The afflicted creature's skin gradually decays. The afflicted creature
has disadvantage on
Charisma checks and is vulnerable to all damage types. ·Mindfire: The afflicted creature's mind is hot. The afflicted creature has
disadvantage on Intelligence checks
and Intelligence saving throws, and is treated as if it were under the effects of a confused spell in combat. ·Seizure: The afflicted
creature's body shakes
violently. The afflicted creature has disadvantage on Dexterity checks and Dexterity saving throws, and on Dexterity-based attack
rolls. · Slimy Doom: The victim begins to bleed uncontrollably. The diseased creature has disadvantage on Constitution
checks and Constitution
saving throws. In addition, each time the creature takes damage, it is stunned until the end of its next turn.

Name: x
column22:
· You gain control over
a 100-cubic-foot volume of air that you can see. When you cast this spell, choose one of the following effects. This effect remains
in effect for the duration of the spell unless you use
an action later in your turn to change it to a different effect. You can also use your action to suspend an effect or restart a suspended
effect. · Gusts: The air you control creates a gust of wind that blows continuously in a horizontal direction of your choice. You
choose the strength of the wind: calm, moderate, or strong. If the wind is strong or strong, ranged weapon attacks made to enter or
leave the area or to travel through it
have disadvantage on attack rolls. If the wind is strong, creatures moving against the wind use up 1 extra foot of movement for each
foot they move. Downdraft: The air you manipulate creates a downward current that starts at the top of the space and descends.
Ranged weapon attacks made to travel through it or against creatures in it have disadvantage on attack rolls. The first time a
creature flies into the affected space each turn, or
starts its turn in the affected space while flying, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it falls prone. Updraft: The
air you manipulate creates an upward current that starts at the bottom of the space and ascends. A creature that ends its fall in the
space takes only half damage from falling. A creature in the space can jump vertically up to 10 feet higher than it
normally would.

Level:

can create an object of vegetable matter (such as textiles, rope, wood, etc.). You can also create an object of mineral matter (such
as stone, crystal, metal, etc.). The created object must be within a 5-
foot cube and its shape and material must be something you have seen before. ·The duration of the spell is determined by the
material of the
created object. If the created object is made up of multiple materials, its existence duration is the shortest of them. Material vegetable matter

Duration:
· Threads of dark
power extend from your fingertips, piercing up to 5 Small or Medium corpses you can see within range. Each corpse immediately
rises to its feet and becomes undead. You decide whether it's a zombie or a skeleton (see the Monster Manual for zombie and
skeleton statistics), and they gain a bonus on attack and damage rolls equal to your spellcasting ability modifier. You can use your
bonus action to mentally direct the creatures you create with this spell, giving them
the same commands. The creature must be within 60 feet of you to receive commands. You determine the actions and
movements of the manipulated creature on its next turn. Alternatively, you can give a broad command, such as guarding a certain
room or corridor. If you don't give orders, the creature only defends itself against hostile creatures. Once given orders, the creature
continues to carry out the orders until the task is completed.
Your control over the creatures lasts until the spell ends, after which they immediately return to their
inanimate state. Higher-level spellcasting effects. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, you can
animate two additional corpses for each level above 5th that the slot used is higher.

column23:
· You become
invisible, and an illusory duplicate
of you appears where you are standing. The duplicate persists until the spell's duration ends; but if you attack or cast a spell,
the invisibility effect
ends. · You can use your action to move the duplicate at up to twice your speed, and can have it gesture, speak, and act in any
way you specify. · You can see through the duplicate's eyes and hear with its ears as if you were in its place. You can switch
between your own senses and the duplicate's as a bonus action on your turn. While you use the
duplicate's senses, you are blinded and deafened of everything around you.

Duration:
· You attempt to reshape the memories of another
creature. Force a creature you can see to make a Wisdom saving throw. If you're in combat with the creature, it has advantage
on this saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is charmed by you for the duration of the spell. The charmed target is
incapacitated and unable to sense its
surroundings, but it can still hear you. If it takes any damage or becomes the target of another spell, the spell ends and the
target's memories are not modified. · While the charm lasts, you can alter the target's memory of an event that lasted no longer
than ten minutes within the past 24 hours. You can permanently erase all memories of the event, or
cause the target to recall the event in perfect detail, or even alter the target's memory of the event, or create a memory of
something else. You must describe the alteration in words to the target's memory, and the target must be able to understand
you in order for the altered memory to be implanted. The target's mind fills in any missing details from your description.
If the spell ends before you finish describing the altered memory, the target's memory is not altered, but the altered memory is
implanted in the target's mind when the spell ends. Altered memories may not necessarily affect a creature's behavior,
especially if the altered memory goes against the target's nature, alignment, or beliefs. If you implant an illogical memory (such
as you implanting a memory of how much it
enjoyed bathing in acid), the target may simply ignore the memory or regard it as a nightmare. The DM may also decide that an
altered memory
is too absurd to affect a creature's critical behavior. Casting remove curse or greater restoration on the target restores the
target's true memory. Upgraded spellcasting effect. When cast using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, you can alter the
target's memory of events that occurred within the past 7 days (6th level), 30 days (7th level), 1 year (8th level), or any time in the past (9th level).

Name: Raise Dead

Casting Time: A diamond worth at least 500 gp is required for the spell
V Verbal:
· You touch a dead creature,
bringing it back to life. The creature must have been dead no more than 10 days ago. If the creature's spirit is willing and able to
return to its body, it is reborn with 1 hit point. The spell also neutralizes poisons and nonmagical diseases in the creature's body, but
has no effect on magical diseases, curses, and similar effects; if these effects are not cured before the resurrection, they continue
to be in effect when the creature regains life. The spell cannot raise undead creatures. · The spell heals all fatal
wounds, but cannot restore missing body parts. If the creature is missing a body part or organ that is necessary for its survival
(such as a head), the spell automatically fails. · Returning
from the dead is a painful experience. The resurrected target takes a -4 penalty on subsequent attack rolls, saving throws, and ability
checks. Each time the target completes a long rest, the penalty is reduced by 1, stacking until the penalty is eliminated
completely.

that enters the portal instantly appears within 5 feet of the target circle (or in the nearest unoccupied space, if that space is
occupied). Many
temples, guilds, and other important places have permanent teleportation circles somewhere in their midst. Each of these
circles has its own rune sequence—a string of magical runes arranged in a specific order. When you first gain the ability to
cast this spell, you know the rune sequences for two permanent circles on the Material Plane (determined by your DM), and
you can learn more rune sequences as you travel. You can memorize a new rune sequence by spending a minute studying it carefully.
Healing Touch (1/day). A celestial creature touches another creature. The target magically regains 2d8 + the spell's level of
hit points.

#REF!: with at least one round of ammunition in it
School:
· You cast this spell on your quiver, causing it to
create an endless supply of nonmagical ammunition out of thin air. When you reach into the quiver, ammunition leaps into your
hand. · Each of your turns until
the spell ends, you can use a bonus action to make two attacks with weapons that use ammunition from the quiver. Each
time you make such an attack, the magic on the quiver automatically creates a replacement round of the same nonmagical
ammunition. When the spell ends, all ammunition created by the spell disintegrates and disappears. The spell ends when
you no longer hold the quiver.

Duration:
· You choose a point within range and cause an explosion of psychic
energy there. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make an Intelligence saving throw.
Creatures with an Intelligence score of 2 or lower are unaffected by the spell. A creature that fails its saving throw takes 8d6
psychic damage, or half as much on a successful one. · A creature that fails its saving throw has its mind clouded for 1
minute. During the duration, roll a d6 and subtract that amount from each attack roll, ability check, and Constitution saving
throw made to maintain concentration. At the end of each of the target's turns, it can retry its Intelligence saving
throw to end the effect on itself.

Spell Description:
· You gain the ability to move
and manipulate creatures or objects with your mind. When you cast this spell, you can use your mind to cause the effects
detailed below to occur on a creature or object you can see within range. You can also do so as an action on any of your
subsequent turns during the spell's duration. You can affect the same target round after round, or choose a new target at any
time. If you change the target, the
previous target is no longer affected by the spell. ·Creature: You can attempt to move a Huge or smaller creature. Make an
ability check with your spellcasting key attribute opposed by the target creature's Strength check. If you win the contest, you
can move the creature 30 feet in any direction (including straight up), but you cannot move it out of range. Until the end of your
next turn, the creature is restrained by your telekinetic grasp. A
creature lifted upwards is suspended in midair. On subsequent turns, you can make the same contested attempt to
continue to hold the creature (using an action). Object: You can attempt to move an object weighing no more than 1,000
pounds. If the object is not worn or carried by any creature, you can automatically move it 30 feet in any direction, but not out of range.

If you cast this spell on a ceiling, the mud will fall. Each creature below the mud as it falls must make a Dexterity
Saving Throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 4d8 points of bludgeoning damage; on a successful save, the creature
takes half as much damage. Transmute Mud to Rock: For the duration of the spell, nonmagical mud or quicksand in an area up to 10
feet deep transforms into soft rock. Creatures in the transformed mud make a Dexterity saving throw. On a successful save, the creature
moves safely to an unoccupied surface. On a failed save, the creature is restrained by the rock. A restrained creature, or one that can
reach it, can use an action to attempt to free itself with a Strength check (DC 20). The rock has 15 AC and 25 hit points, and is immune
to poison and psychic damage.
Name: Transmute Rock

V Verbal:
· You can enter a tree and move from inside it to another tree of the same kind within 500 feet. Both trees must be alive and
at least as large as you. You must spend 5 feet of movement to enter a tree. You know the location of all other trees of the same kind
within 500 feet of you after you enter the tree. As part of your movement to enter the tree, you can move to one of these trees of the
same kind or walk out of the tree you are in. You appear at a point of your choice within 5 feet of your destination tree, spending 5 feet
of movement to do so. If you run out of movement, you appear somewhere within 5 feet of the tree you entered. · You can use this
teleportation ability once per round for the duration of the spell.
You must end your turn outside the tree.

Ritual: A pinch of pure gemstone ground into powder
Range:
·An invisible wall of force appears at a point you designate within range. The direction of the wall is up to you: you
can make it a horizontal or vertical barrier, or you can make it tilted. It can float in the air or stand on the ground. You can shape it into a
hemisphere or a sphere (up to 10 feet in radius), or into a flat surface made up of ten 10-foot-by-10-foot squares, each of which must
be connected to at least one other square. Regardless of the shape, the wall is always 1/4 inch thick. The wall of force lasts until the
spell ends. If the wall forms through a creature's space, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (you decide which side). ·Nothing
can physically pass through a wall of force. It is immune to all damage and cannot be dispelled by Dispel Magic, but it can be instantly
destroyed by Disintegrate. The wall of force
can extend into the Ethereal Plane, thus blocking travel through the wall into the Ethereal Plane. ·Additional: The designer explains that
teleportation effects such as Anywhere Door can be used inside and outside the wall of force.

which must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or vanish, banished to another point in the timestream and causing the attack to miss or
the spell to be wasted. At the start of the target creature's next turn, the target reappears at its last location or in the nearest
unoccupied space. The target has no memory of you casting the spell or being affected by it. · Ringcasting effect. When you cast this
spell using a spell
slot of 6th level or higher, you can specify one additional target for each slot level above 5th. All targets must be within 30 feet of each
other.

kind of nonmagical rock in the area turns into an equal amount of thin, flowable mud
for the duration of the spell.

,Wall of Light,5,Evocation,x,1 Action,120 ft.,V,S,M,A Hand Mirror,Concentrate
Ritual:
· A bright, shimmering wall
appears at a point of your choice within range. The direction of this wall of light is up to you: you can make it a horizontal or
vertical ward, or at an angle. It can float in midair or rest on a solid surface. The wall can be up to 60 feet long, up to 10 feet high,
and up to 5 feet thick. The wall blocks sight, but creatures and objects can pass through it. It sheds bright light out to 120 feet
and dim light an additional 120
feet. · Each creature in the area when the wall of light appears must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the
creature takes 4d8 radiant damage and is blinded 1d8. · minutes. If the saving throw succeeds, it takes only half damage and
is not blinded. A blinded creature can remake its Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the blindness
on itself if it succeeds. Creatures that end their turns
in the wall's area also take 4d8 radiant damage. · Until the spell ends, you can use your action to send a ray of radiance from
the wall that strikes a creature you can see within 60 feet of it. Make a ranged spell attack roll. If you hit, the target takes 4d8
radiant damage. Whether you hit or miss, the length of the wall is reduced by 10 feet. If the
length of the wall is reduced to 0 feet, the spell ends. · Upgraded spellcasting effect. When you cast this spell using a spell slot
of 6th level or higher, increase the damage by 1d8 for each level higher than 5th level the slot used is.

Level:
·A solid, nonmagical wall of stone appears at a point you choose within range. The
wall is 6 inches thick and is made up of ten 10-foot-by-10-foot squares. Each square must be connected to at least one other
square.
Alternatively, you can choose to make the wall of ten 10-foot-by-20-foot squares, but only 3 inches thick. ·If the wall forms
through a creature's space, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (you decide which side). If the creature is completely
surrounded by the wall (or by the wall and another solid surface), it can make a Dexterity saving throw. A
successful save allows it to use a reaction to move at its normal speed to avoid being surrounded by the wall. You can shape
the stone wall into any shape you want, but it cannot occupy the same space as other creatures or objects. The wall does not
have to be perpendicular to the ground or have a foundation; it must extend from a stable existing stone mass. Thus, you can
use this spell to create a bridge across a ravine or to build a ramp. A
suspended slab of stone that spans more than 20 feet requires support, so the area of the slab is halved. You can roughly
shape the stone wall to create crenellations, battlements, and so on. The wall is a stone object that can be broken by damage.
Each slab has
an AC of 15, and the wall has 30 hit points for every inch of thickness. When a slab is reduced to 0 hit points, it is destroyed,
and adjacent slabs may also collapse (at the DM's discretion). If you maintain concentration on the spell for the entire duration,
the
stone wall remains permanent and cannot be dispelled. If you fail to do so, the stone wall disappears when the spell ends.

Name: Evocation

call forth the spirits of nature
to fight your foes. Choose a point you can see within range. The spirit animates trees, rocks, and grass in a 60-foot cube
centered
on that point until the spell ends. ·Grasses and Undergrowth: Ground covered with grass or undergrowth in the cube becomes
difficult terrain for your foes. ·Trees: At the start of each of your turns, each of your foes
within 10 feet of any tree in the cube must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 4d6 slashing damage from the swinging
branches of its branches. ·Roots and Vines: At the end of each of your turns, a creature of your choice standing on the ground
in the cube must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be restrained until the spell ends. The bound
creature can use its action to make a Strength (Athletics) check against your spellcasting DC, ending the effect on itself if
successful. Rocks: As a bonus action on your turn, you can cause a loose rock in a cube to be hurled at a creature you can see
that is also in the cube. If it hits, the target takes 3d8 nonmagical bludgeoning damage and must succeed on
a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone. Wrath of Nature,,√,√,,,,,,,,Shanatha's Guide to Everything,Summoning a Dragon

You summon a dragon spirit. It manifests in an unoccupied space within range. Its corporeal form uses the dragon spirit's statistics. When you cast this 
Share Resistances. When you summon a dragon, choose a damage resistance it has, and you gain that damage resistance until the spell ends.
ActionMultiattack. The dragon uses its breath weapon and makes a number of gnawing attacks equal to half the spell's level (rounded down). Rend. Melee

colorful energy in a 30-foot
cone. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw or take 2d6 points of damage of the type you choose to which the dragon is resistant. On a
success, the damage is half as much.

Range:
· You create two linked portals. Choose two points on the ground you can see, one within 10 feet of you and the
other within 500 feet. A 10-foot-diameter circular portal then opens at each point. If the points you choose are occupied by creatures, the spell fails and is
expended. The edges of the portals are shimmering, two-dimensional circles filled with mist, and the entire thing is suspended vertically a few feet above the
ground. Only one side of the circle is visible (you choose); that is the side on which the portal works. Any creature that enters
one of the portals exits through the other, as if the two portals were adjacent. Walking through the inactive side of the portal has no effect. The mist that fills
the portal obstructs vision, so no image can be seen. You can use a bonus action
on your turn to change the direction of the portal.

· You raise a wall of spinning magical blades. The wall appears at a location you designate within range and
remains until the spell's duration ends. You can choose to create a straight wall no longer than 100 feet, no higher than 20 feet, and no thicker than 5 feet; or
a circular wall
no higher than 60 feet in diameter, no higher than 20 feet, and no thicker than 5 feet. The wall provides three-quarters cover for creatures behind it. The space
occupied by the wall is treated as difficult terrain.
