· The creature looks like the dragon you chose, which determines some of the characteristics of its statistics. The creature disappears when the spell ends or
when it
reaches 0 hit points. · The creature is friendly to you and your companions. In combat, the creature shares initiative with you, and it acts after your turn ends.
It obeys your verbal commands (no actions are required). If you don't give a command, the creature takes the Dodge action and uses its movement to avoid
danger. ·
Higher-level spellcasting effects. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, use the corresponding level to determine the data in the
statistics column related to the spell's level.

· Any creature entering the wall's area for the first time in a turn, or starting its turn in the area, must make a Dexterity saving throw.
On a failed save, it takes 6d10 points of slashing damage. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage.

Spell Description:
· You cause six stone pillars to rise from the ground
within sight of you. Each pillar is a cylinder 5 feet in diameter and up to 30 feet tall. The ground above the pillars must have room for
its diameter, and you can target the ground under the feet of a Medium creature or smaller. Each pillar has an AC of 5 and 30 hit
points. When its hit points are reduced to 0, it turns to rubble, creating an area of difficult terrain in a 10-foot-radius area. Each 5-footdiameter
area of rubble takes at least 1 minute to clear manually.
If a pillar rises beneath a creature's feet, the creature must make a Dexterity saving throw or be lifted up by the pillar. A creature can
choose to fail this saving throw. If a
pillar is held back from reaching its full height by a ceiling or other obstruction, a creature on top of it takes 6d6 points of bludgeoning
damage and is restrained, unable to move between the pillar and the obstruction. A restrained creature can take an action to make a
Strength or Dexterity check (the creature's choice) against the spell's saving throw DC. If successful, the creature is no longer
restrained and must
choose to move from the pillar or fall off. Increased-level spellcasting effect. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or
higher, you can raise two additional pillars for each level above 6th that the slot used is.
Name: Bones of the Earth

Level:
· You send a bolt of lightning that shoots at a designated target you can see within range. After passing the
first target, the lightning splits into three and jumps to up to three additional targets within 30 feet of that target. The target of the
lightning can be a creature
or an object, but each bolt must designate a different target. · Each target must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save,
the creature takes 10d8 points of lightning damage, or half as much damage on a successful one. · Higher-level spellcasting effect.
When casting this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, for each level higher than 6th the slot you use, the lightning splits into
one more bolt that shoots at a different target after the jump.

M Materials: Ground black pearl powder worth at least 500 gp
Duration:
·A wave of negative energy
is released from a point within the casting range, impacting a 60-foot-radius
sphere. Creatures in the area must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 points of necrotic damage on a failed
saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one. ·Upgraded spellcasting effect. When casting
this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the spell's damage increases by 2d6 for each level higher than the 6th level you
use.
Name: Circle of Death

Range:
· You summon a fey of CR 6 or lower, or a beast spirit of CR 6 or lower. The
summoned creature manifests in an unoccupied space you can see within range. The fey disappears when its hit points drop to 0 or
when the spell ends. · The summoned fey remains friendly to you and your companions. You roll initiative for each fey you summon,
and it takes its turn accordingly. The fey obeys all verbal commands you give it (without your action), provided that the command does
not violate its alignment. If you give no
commands, the creature protects itself from hostile creatures or takes no actions if there are no hostile creatures. If your concentration
is broken, the fey does not vanish, but you lose control of it. A fey that loses control becomes hostile to you and your companions,
ready to attack. An uncontrolled fey cannot be dismissed by
you, and it vanishes 1 hour after your summoning
begins. The fey's exact statistics are at the discretion of the DM. Higher-level spellcasting effects. When casting this spell using a
spell slot of 7th level or higher, increase the challenge rating of the summoned creature by 1 for each level
higher than 6th that the slot you use is.

Casting Time: A statue of yourself made of ivory and decorated with gems, worth at least 1,500 gp
V Verbal:
·Choose a spell of
5th level or lower that you can cast. It must have a casting time of 1 action and must be able to target yourself. You cast this spell as
a caused spell
S Posture:
that is, as part of a triggered spell you are casting, consuming both the spell and the triggered spell's spell slot. The
caused spell does not take effect immediately, but instead triggers its effect when a certain condition occurs. When you cast both spells, you must describe the 
Casting Water Breathing with a trigger spell ensures that Water Breathing automatically triggers when you are submerged in water
or
another liquid. · The effects of a triggered spell take effect immediately when the corresponding condition first occurs, and the
triggered spell ends after that, whether you intended it to or not. · A triggered spell affects only you, even if it normally targets other
targets. You can have only one triggered spell active at a time. If you cast it again while already casting one, the previous
triggered spell ends immediately. In addition, a triggered spell ends immediately if its material
component is no longer on your character.

Ritual:
· As you utter a complex spell, you pierce yourself
with a jeweled dagger, taking 2d4 piercing damage that cannot be reduced by any means. You then drip blood onto the other
components of the spell and touch them, transforming them into a special
construct called a Homunculus. · See the Monster Manual for the Homunculus's statistics. It is your loyal companion and dies with
you. Each time you finish a long rest, and if the Homunculus is on the same plane as you, you can choose to spend up to half your
Hit Dice, roll each die and add your Constitution modifier, then your maximum hit points are reduced by the sum of the numbers,
and the Homunculus's maximum hit points and current hit points are increased by that number. This process can reduce your hit
points to no less than 1. The hit points of both you and your homunculus are restored when you
finish your next long rest, and the reduction in your maximum hit points cannot be removed until your homunculus dies. You
can have only one homunculus at a time. If you cast this spell while your
homunculus is still alive, the spell fails.

Level:
·Specify the remains of up to three Medium or Small humanoids within range, and turn each corpse into a ghoul
under your control
(the specific game data for these creatures is up to the DM). This spell can only be cast at night. On any of your turns, you can
use a bonus action to mentally command any creature you have called up with this spell within 120 feet. (If you are controlling
multiple creatures, your commands can be given to all or some of them at once, but only to the same order.) You decide the
actions and movements of the controlled creatures on their next turn. Alternatively, you can choose to give a general order, such
as to guard a room or corridor. A creature that does not receive
your command will only defend itself against hostile creatures. Once given an order, the creature continues to follow your order
until the task is completed. The controlled creature only obeys your orders for 24 hours. If you cast this spell again before the current
24-hour period ends, your control over the creature is extended
by another 24 hours. This use of the spell only extends your control over up to three creatures you created with this spell; it does
not create new creatures. Higher-level spellcasting. When you cast this spell using a 7th-level spell slot, you can raise or maintain
four ghouls. When you cast this spell using an 8th-level spell slot, you can raise or maintain five ghouls, or two ghasts, or two
wights. When you cast this spell using a 9th-level spell slot, you can raise or
maintain six ghouls, or three ghasts, or three wights, or two mummies.

Name: Druidic Grove
column23: A mistletoe harvested with a golden

#REF!: sickle under the light of a full moon
Spell Name: as a consumable for this spell
School:
· You call upon a nature spirit to guard an area
outdoors or underground. The area can be as small as a 30-foot cube or as large as a 90-foot cube. Buildings and other
structures are excluded from the affected area. If you cast this spell on the
same area each day for a year, the spell lasts until dispelled. · The spell causes the following effects in the area. When you
cast this spell, you can designate a creature as a companion that is immune to
these effects. You can also specify a command that makes anyone who speaks the command aloud immune to these effects.
·The entire protected area radiates magic. A dispel magic spell cast over the area, if successful, removes only one of the
following effects, not the entire area. The spellcaster can choose one effect to end. The spell is dispelled only when all effects
end. ·Solid Fog: You can place thick fog over the ground to fill any number of 5-foot squares, heavily concealing it. The fog is
up to 10 feet high. Each foot you move through the fog costs an extra 2 feet of
movement. To creatures immune to this effect, the fog obscures nothing and appears as green dots of light floating in the air.
·Grasping Undergrowth: You can place tangled vines and weeds over any number of 5-foot squares of ground not covered in
fog, as if affected by entangle. These weeds and vines appear pliable to creatures
immune to this effect, and can even be reshaped into makeshift chairs and beds. ·Grove Guardians: You can animate up to
four trees in the area, causing them to uproot from the ground. These trees have the same statistics as the Awakened tree in
the Monster Manual, except that they cannot speak and are covered in druidic symbols on their bark. If any creature not
immune to this effect enters the protected area, the grove wardens fight them until the intruder is driven away or killed. The
grove wardens also obey verbal commands you give within the area (without your action). If you give them no commands and
there are no intruders, the grove wardens do not act. The grove wardens cannot leave the
protected area. At the end of the spell, the magic animating them also fades, and they reroot (if possible). Additional Spell
Effect: You can choose one of the following magic effects to place in the
protected area. · Place a continuous Gust of Wind effect at two locations
of your choice. · Place a Spike Growth effect at one location of your
choice. · Place a Wall of Wind effect at two locations of your choice. · To creatures immune to this effect, the wind is a sweetsmelling
breeze, and the thorny fields are harmless.

Name: Shanatha's Guide to Everything
column26:
· For the duration of the spell, your eyes become dark holes filled with terrible power. Designate a creature you can
see within 60 feet and force it to make a Wisdom saving throw. If it fails the saving throw, it suffers one of the following effects
(your choice). On each of your turns before the spell ends, you can use your
action to designate a target. You can't designate a creature that has already made a successful saving throw. · Asleep: The
target falls unconscious. It wakes up again if it takes damage or if another creature uses an action to shake it. Panicked: The
target is panicked by you. It must take the Dash action and move on each of its turns, taking the shortest, safest route possible
to get away from you until it runs out of options. If the target moves more than 60 feet away from you and can no longer see you, the spell ends.

· Sickened: The target has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks. The target can make another Wisdom saving throw at
the end of each of its turns. This effect ends on a success.

· This spell searches for a specific location on the same plane that
you are familiar with. The spell finds the shortest, most direct way to it. If the destination you are looking for is on another plane, is
constantly moving (such as a moving fortress), or is not specifically described (such as a green dragon's lair")

direction of the destination as long as you are on the same plane as the destination for the duration of the spell. When moving
toward a destination and encountering a fork in the road

Level:
· You attempt to turn a creature you can see within range to stone. If the target's body is made
of flesh, it must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed saving throw, its flesh becomes stiff and restrained.
On a successful saving throw, it is unaffected by the effect. · A creature restrained by this spell must make another Constitution
saving throw at the end of each of its turns. After three successful saving throws, the spell ends. After three failed saving throws,
the creature turns to stone and is treated as petrified for the duration. The successes and failures
do not need to be consecutive; just keep track of each until one party has three. · If the creature's
petrified body is destroyed, it suffers the same damage when it returns to its original form. · If you maintain concentration for the
maximum duration for the spell, the creature's transformation to stone
remains until it is removed.

amount of holy water, rare incense, and at least 1,000 gp worth of dusted rubies
column28:
· You create a ward against magical travel
covering up to 40,000 square feet of ground and 30 feet above it. For the duration of the spell, creatures cannot teleport into the
area or use portals (such as those created by the Gate spell) to enter it. This spell renders the area inaccessible to planar
travel, so creatures cannot access it via the Astral Plane, the Ethereal Plane, the Feywild,
the Shadowfell, or by plane shift. In addition, the spell can damage creatures of your choice. Choose one or more of the
following: celestials, elementals, fey, fiends, and undead. The first time a creature enters the spell's area or starts its turn in it
during a turn, it takes 5d10 points of radiant damage or necrotic damage (you choose which when you cast

Name: Empowerment of Ice

Spell Description:
· Until the spell ends,
rock particles cover your body, and you
gain the following benefits: · You gain resistance to bludgeoning, piercing,
and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks. · As an action, you can create a small earthquake in the ground in a 15-foot
radius around you. Other creatures on the ground must
succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or fall prone. · You can move over difficult terrain created by dirt or stone without
expending additional movement. You can move through solid dirt or stone as if you were moving through air. This does not
make the material you pass through less solid, but you cannot end your movement in the material. If you end your movement,
you are expelled to the nearest unoccupied space, the spell ends, and you are stunned until the end of your next turn.
Name: Empowerment of Stone

create a 15-foot cube of whistling wind centered on a point you can see within 60 feet of you. Each creature in that space must
make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 2d10 points of bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much

M Materials:
· Your soul
leaves your body and enters the container that is the material component of the spell, while your body becomes trance-like.
While your soul is in the container, you are aware of your surroundings as if you were in the container's location. You cannot
move or use reactions, and your only actions are to project your soul up to 100 feet out of the container, return to your
still-living body (ending the spell), or attempt to possess the body of another humanoid. · You can possess any humanoid
you can see within 100 feet of you (creatures protected by Protection from Evil and Good or Magic Circle cannot be possessed).
The target must make a Charisma saving throw. If you fail the save, your soul enters the target's body and the target's soul is
trapped in the container. If you succeed, the target resists your
possession, and you cannot attempt to possess the creature again for 24 hours. · Upon successful possession, the target's
body is controlled by you. Your game data is replaced with the creature's attribute data, but you retain your alignment and
Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma attribute values. Your class feature benefits are also maintained while possessed, but you cannot use any class features 
Additionally, the possessed creature's soul can use its own senses to see from inside the container, but it can neither move nor
use
actions. While possessing a body, if the container is within 100 feet of you, you can use an action to return from the host's body to
the container and return the host's soul to its own body. If the host's body dies while you are in the host's body, you must make a
Charisma saving throw against the spell's save DC. On a successful save and the container is within 100 feet of you, you return
to the container. On a failed save,
you die. If the container is destroyed or the spell ends, your soul immediately returns to your own body. If your body is more than
100 feet away or your body dies when you try to return to your own body, you die. If the soul of another creature was in the container
when the container is destroyed, and that creature's body is still alive and within 100 feet of it, its soul returns to its body.
Otherwise, that creature dies. When the spell ends, its container is destroyed.

charmed are immune to this effect. Your suggestion must make the action sound reasonable. Asking a creature to stab itself,
throw itself on the spear, sacrifice itself, or do anything obviously harmful will immediately cancel the effect of
the spell. ·Each target must make a Wisdom saving throw. If the save fails, it will do the action you describe to the best of its ability.

request. · You can also describe a specific condition that occurs during the duration as a condition for triggering a special action.

of this
spell on that creature ends. · Upgraded spellcasting effect. When you cast this spell using a 7th-level spell slot, the duration becomes
10 days. When you cast this spell using an 8th-level spell slot, the duration becomes 30 days. When you cast this spell using a
9th-level spell slot, the duration becomes one year and one day.

Casting Time:
·Specify a square of terrain within
range that is no longer than 40 feet on a side, and reshape the dirt, sand, or clay in the area in any way you like. You can raise
or lower the ground in the area, make or fill a ditch, raise or level a hill, or shape a pillar. The maximum length of the terrain being
altered cannot exceed half the longest side of the entire area. Thus, if you affect a 40-foot square, you can create a pillar up to 20
feet high, raise or lower the ground up to 20 feet, dig a trench up to 20 feet deep, and so on. These changes take 10 minutes to
complete. ·For every 10 minutes of concentration you maintain for the spell, you can choose a new
area of terrain to affect. ·Because changes to the terrain occur so slowly, creatures in the area are usually not
trapped or injured by the movement of the ground. ·This spell cannot change natural rock or stone buildings. However, the stone
and buildings will still be changed to adapt to the changes in the terrain.
If you change the terrain in a way that makes the building unstable, it may collapse. ·In addition, this spell cannot directly affect
plant growth. Instead, the removed soil will take away any plants growing on it.

Spell Description:
· A ball of frozen energy shoots from
your fingertips to a designated point within range, where it bursts into a 60-foot-radius sphere. Each creature in the area must make
a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 10d6 points of cold damage on a failed save. Half as much damage on a
successful save. · If the ball of ice strikes a body of water or a liquid surface that is primarily water (not including creatures
composed of water), the surface of the water it touches freezes in a 6-inch-thick, 30-foot-wide square. Any creature swimming
within is trapped by the ice. A trapped creature can use an action to make a Strength
check against the spell save DC to break free. · You can delay firing the ice after completing this spell. A small ball of ice the size
of a projectile will form on your hand, and it will feel cold to the touch. You or any creature that has taken the ice ball from your hand
can throw it at any time (with a range of 40 feet) or sling it (with a sling's normal range), and break it with an impact to produce the
same effect as when casting the spell normally. You can also set the ice ball without breaking it.
The ball will automatically burst after it lasts for 1 minute without breaking. · Upgraded spellcasting effect. When casting this spell
using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each level higher than the 6th level of the
slot you use.
Name: Otiluke's Freezing Sphere

Range:
·Specify a creature you can see within range, and cause the target creature to do
a funny dance on the spot: it will shuffle,
stamp, and jump for the duration. Creatures that cannot be charmed are immune to the spell. ·The dancing creature must use
all of its movement to dance on the spot, and it has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws and attack rolls. While the target is
affected by this spell, other creatures have advantage on attack rolls against it. The dancing creature can use an action to make
a Wisdom saving
throw, which ends the spell if it succeeds.

Duration:
· You invoke the aid of an outsider. This being must be known to
you; it may be a deity, a primordial, a demon lord, or some other planar power. The being sends a celestial, elemental, or fiend in
its service to you, and causes that creature to manifest in an unoccupied space within range. If you know the name of a specific
creature, you can name it when you cast the spell, but you may get a different creature instead (the DM's
choice).· When the creature appears, you cannot force it to do anything. You can request its services in exchange for a reward,
but it is under no obligation to perform them. The task requested can be simple (help us fly across a ravine, or assist in a battle)
or complex (spy on our enemies, or protect us as we raid a dungeon). You must be able to communicate with the creature to
bargain for its
services.· The reward may come in a variety of forms. A celestial creature might demand a sizable donation of gold or magic
items to an allied temple, while a fiend might demand a sacrifice or a gift of treasure. Some creatures may ask you to perform a
task in exchange for their services.
As a rough guide, a task that can be performed by the minute requires a payment of 100 gp per minute. A task that can be
performed by the hour requires a payment of 1,000 gp per hour. A task that can be performed by the day (up to 10 days) requires
a payment of 10,000 gp per day. The DM can adjust the specific payment based on the circumstances in which you cast this
spell. If the task is consistent with the creature's code of conduct, the payment may be halved or even abandoned. Risk-free tasks
generally require only half the suggested payment,
while particularly dangerous tasks may require a larger gift. Creatures rarely accept tasks that seem suicidal. After the creature
completes the task, or when the agreed-upon service period is up, if the task is appropriate and possible, the creature returns to
its home plane before reporting back to you. If you cannot agree to the price of the creature's services, it returns to its home
plane immediately. ·Creatures
called to join your party count as party members and share experience gained normally.

Spell Name:
·This spell seizes the soul of a dead humanoid and imprisons it in the cage you use as the spell's material component.
The stolen soul remains in the cage until the spell ends or you destroy the cage, which also ends the spell. While you have a
soul in the cage, you can use it in any of the ways described below. You can use a trapped soul up to six times in this way.
Once you use the soul a sixth time, it is released and the
spell ends. While the soul is trapped, the dead humanoid creature it originated from cannot be resurrected.
Steal Life: You can use a bonus action to drain vitality from a soul and regain 2d8 hit points. Query Soul: You ask the soul a
question (no action required) and receive a brief answer as telepathic communication in any language you can understand.
The soul knows only what it knew in life, but it must answer truthfully and
to the best of its ability. The answer is no more than a sentence or two, and may have hidden meanings. Borrow Experience:
You can use a bonus action to let the soul's life experience bolster you, giving you advantage on your next attack roll, ability
check, or saving
throw. If you do not use this buff before the start of your next turn, it disappears. Eyes of the Dead: You can use an action to
name a location this humanoid has seen in life, and if you are on the same plane as that location, you can create an invisible
sensor there. This sensor lasts until your concentration ends, up to 10 minutes (as if you were concentrating on a spell). You
receive visual and auditory information from this
sensor as if you were using your own senses at that location. Creatures that can see this sensor (such as by using the See
Invisibility spell or having true seeing) see a translucent image of the victim you have caged.

20 feet, and no thicker than 5 feet. In addition, the wall of thorns blocks vision. ·

on a failed save, or half

Level:
· You and up to ten willing creatures you can see within range become vaporous for the duration of the spell, with
the appearance of a cloud. A creature in this cloud form has a fly speed of 300 feet and is resistant to damage from nonmagical weapons. A creature in this form has no 
You can take no other actions except to return to your original form. It takes 1 minute to return to your original form, during which
time the creature is incapacitated and cannot move. You can change back to cloud form again before the spell ends, and it
also takes 1 minute to change again. If the creature is flying in cloud form when the spell ends, it descends at a rate of 60 feet
per round for 1 minute until it lands safely. If the creature does not land after 1 minute of descending, it falls normally for the
remainder of the distance.

Spell Description:
· You and up to five willing creatures within 5 feet of
you are instantly transported to a shelter you have set up. You and the creatures you teleport with appear in the nearest
unoccupied space next to the location you specified when you prepared the shelter (see below). If you cast this spell without first
preparing a sanctuary,
the spell has no effect. · You must be at a temple to your deity or a location closely associated with that deity to set up the
sanctuary, and then cast the spell there. If you attempt to cast the spell in a location that is not dedicated to your deity, the spell
has no effect.
Name: Word of Recall

M Materials: A platinum-plated dragon scale worth at least 500 gp
Spell Description:
· You create a field of shimmering silvery light around a creature of your choice within range (you can choose yourself).
The field radiates a 5-foot glow. The creature protected by the field gains the following benefits:
√ Cover: The creature has half cover. √
Damage Resistance: The creature gains resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, and poison
damage. √ Evasion: If the creature is affected by an effect that allows a successful Dexterity saving throw to reduce damage by
half, it instead takes no damage on a successful save, or half
damage on a failed one. · On subsequent turns, as a bonus action, you can move the field to another creature within 60 feet of
the field.
Name: Fizban's Platinum Shield

V Verbal:
· You summon a celestial of CR 4 or lower and cause it to manifest in an
unoccupied space you can see within range. The celestial disappears when it reaches 0 hit points or when the spell ends. · The
summoned celestial becomes friendly to you and
your companions. You roll initiative for the summoned celestial, which takes its turn. The celestial obeys all verbal commands
you give it (without requiring your actions), as long as the command does not violate its alignment. If you give no commands, the
creature defends itself against hostile creatures, or takes no actions if there are none. · The exact values of the celestial are up
to the DM. · Upgraded
spellcasting effects. When you cast this spell
using a 9th-level spell slot, you summon a celestial with a challenge rating of 5 or lower.

Spell Description:
· Seven
star-shaped points of light appear above your head and circle around you until the spell ends. You can use a bonus action to
expend one point of light to strike a creature or object within 120 feet of you. When you do, make a ranged spell attack roll. If
you hit, the target takes 4d12 radiant damage. Each point of light is consumed whether you hit or not. If you expend the last point
of light, the spell ends prematurely. If you have 4 or more points of light
remaining, they illuminate brightly in a 30-foot radius and dimly for an additional 30 feet. If you have 1 to 3 points of light
remaining, they illuminate dimly for only 30 feet. Upgraded spellcasting effect.
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th level or higher, you create two additional points of light for each level above
7th level.
Name: Crown of Stars

Ritual: A small ball of bat guano and sulfur
Range:
· A beam of yellow light shoots from your
fingertips toward a point of your choice within range, and condenses into a red bead at that point for the duration of the spell.
When the spell ends due to a break in concentration or voluntary decision, the bead explodes into four streams of flame with a
roar and spreads around corners. At this time, each creature within a 20-foot radius of the target point must make a Dexterity
saving throw. A creature that fails the saving throw takes
all accumulated points of fire damage, or half as much damage on a successful one. ·The base damage of this spell is 12d6. If the bead has not exploded 
· If a creature touches the bead before it explodes, that creature must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the spell
ends immediately and the explosion effect is triggered. On a successful save, the creature can throw the bead up to 40 feet away.
If the bead is struck by a creature
or solid object, the spell ends immediately and the explosion effect is
triggered. · Flammable items not carried by clothing in the fire damage area will ignite with flames. · Upgraded spellcasting effect.
When casting this spell using a spell slot of 8th level or higher, the base damage increases by 1d6 for each level
higher than the 7th level you use.

V Verbal:
· You recite a holy mantra, filled with the power of the dawn of creation. Designate any
number of creatures you can see within range, and force each that can hear the
words to make a Charisma saving throw. A
creature that fails its saving throw suffers the following
effects based on its current hit points: √ 50 hit points or fewer:
Deafened for 1 minute. √ 40 hit points
or fewer: Deafened and blinded for 10 minutes. √ 30 hit points or fewer: Deafened, blinded, and stunned for 1 hour. √ 20 hit
points or fewer: Death. · For a celestial, elemental, fey, or fiend that fails its saving throw, its current hit points are ignored, and it is
sent back to its home plane (if it was already there). For the next 24 hours, the creature cannot return to its current plane by any
means except through the effects of a wish spell.

M Materials: A magic item from the target world or a willing creature
Duration:
· You and up to 8
willing creatures fall unconscious for the spell's duration and dream of another world on the Material Plane, such as Oss, Toril,
Krynn, or Eberron. If the spell reaches its full duration, the dream ends when you all meet and a mysterious blue curtain is drawn
aside. The spell then ends, transporting you both physically and mentally to the world of the dream. · To cast this spell, you must
possess a magic item from the target world, and you must know that world exists, even if you don't know its name. Your
destination in the other world is a safe place within 1 mile of where the magic item was created. Alternatively, if one of the targets
was born in another world, you can cast
this spell, but the destination is a safe place within 1 mile of the creature's birthplace. If a creature takes any damage, the spell
ends for that creature and it is not teleported. If you take any damage, the spell ends for you and all other creatures and
none of you are teleported.

Spell Description:
· You enter the overlap between your current
plane and the edge of the Ethereal Plane. You can stay there for the duration of the spell or use your action to dispel the spell.
You can move in any direction. If you move up or down, you spend an extra foot of movement for each foot you move. You can
see and hear your original plane, but everything is grayscale and you cannot see beyond 60 feet. · While on the
Ethereal Plane, only other creatures on the same plane can be affected by you or affect you. Creatures not on the Ethereal
Plane cannot sense you or interact with you unless they have special abilities or
magic to do so. You ignore all objects and effects not on the Ethereal Plane, allowing you to move through objects
on your own plane that you can see. When the spell ends, you return to your original plane, taking up your current spatial
location. If there is already a solid object or creature at your location, you are immediately transported to the nearest unoccupied
spatial location you could occupy,
and take force damage equal to twice your movement feet. This spell has no effect if you are already on the Ethereal Plane or
on a plane that is not connected to the Ethereal Plane (such as an Outer Plane). Higher-level spellcasting effects. When you
cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th level or higher, you may designate up to three additional willing creatures (including you) as
targets for each slot level higher than 7th. These creatures must be
within 10 feet of you when you cast the spell.
Name: Etherealness

V Verbal:
·You magically form a fixed cubic invisible prison around a designated
location within the casting range. You can choose the form of the prison to be caged or sealed. ·A caged prison is a cube with
each side up to 20 feet long. Its walls are made of 1/2-inch thick force fence rods, and each rod is 1/2 inch apart. ·A sealed prison is
a
cube with each side up to 10 feet long. Its walls are sealed by force walls and block all matter and spells from entering and exiting
the
cage. ·When this spell is cast, all creatures completely within the spell area will be trapped in the cage. Creatures that are partially
in the area or larger than the area are pushed outward from the center of the
area until they leave the area completely. ·Creatures within the cage cannot leave by nonmagical means. If the creature attempts
to leave the cage by teleporting or extraplanar travel, it must make a Charisma saving throw. On a successful save, the creature
can use that magic to leave the cage. On a failed save, it cannot leave the cage and the spell or effect is wasted. The cage
also extends to the Ethereal Plane, blocking escape via Ethereal travel. ·This spell cannot be dispelled by Dispel
Magic.
column33:
·You make up to 1 The
terrain in the square area looks, sounds, smells, and even feels like some other type of terrain, though the general shape of the
terrain remains the same. You can make an open plain or a road appear like a wetland, a hill, a chasm, or other difficult or impassable
terrain. You can make a pond appear like a lush meadow, a cliff appear like a gentle slope, or a rocky ravine appear like a wide, flat
road. In addition, you can change
the appearance of buildings or add buildings where none existed. The spell cannot disguise, hide, or add creatures. The illusion
uses sound, sight, touch,
and smell, so it can turn open ground into difficult terrain (or vice versa) or even make it impassable. Any small part of the illusory
terrain (such as a rock or a branch) that is moved outside the spell's area immediately disappears. ·Creatures with true vision can
see through the illusion and perceive the true form of
the terrain; however, all other elements of the illusion are preserved, so a creature aware of the illusion can still physically interact
with the illusion.

When the arcane sword appears, you can make a melee spell attack against a target of your choice within 5 feet of the sword. On

a different target after the move.

to a different plane of existence. You name a destination in general (such as the City of Brass on the Elemental Plane of Fire, or the
palace of Dispater on the second layer of the Nine Hells), and you appear there or in its vicinity. If you want to go to the City of Brass,
you might be transported to its Iron Avenues, its Ash Gate, or across the Sea of Fire from the
city, at the DM's discretion. · Alternatively, if you know the sigil sequence for a teleportation circle on another plane, this spell can
take you there. If the teleportation circle is too small to hold all the creatures you teleport, they appear in the nearest unoccupied
space. You can use this spell to banish an unwilling creature to another plane. Designate a creature within your reach and make a
melee spell attack against it. On a hit, the creature must make a Charisma saving throw. A creature that fails its save is teleported to
a random location on the plane you designate. A creature thus transported must find its own way back to your current plane.

Spell Description:
· You speak a truth word of power, causing intense pain to
a creature you can see within range. If the target has 100 hit points or fewer, it suffers intense pain. Otherwise, the spell has no effect
on it. Creatures immune to charm are also unaffected by this
spell. · If the target suffers this affliction, any speed it has cannot exceed 10 feet. The target has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability
checks, and saving throws except for Constitution saves. Finally, if the target attempts to cast a spell, it must first succeed on a
Constitution saving throw or it fails to cast the spell and
the spell is wasted. · At the end of each of its turns while suffering this affliction, the target can make a Constitution saving throw. If
the save is successful, the affliction ends.
Name: Power Word Pain

Spell Description:
· Eight multicolored rays flash from your hands.
Each ray is a different color and has a different power and effect. Each creature in the 60-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving
throw and roll a d8 to determine which color of ray is in
effect. ·1. Red: The target takes 10d6 points of fire damage on a failed save, or half as
much on a successful one. ·2. Orange: The target takes 10d6 points of acid damage on a failed
save, or half as much on a successful one. ·3. Yellow: The target takes 10d6 points of lightning
damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. ·4. Green: The target takes
10d6 points of poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. ·5.
Blue: The target takes 10d6 points of cold damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. ·6. Indigo: The target is
restrained on a failed save. It must make a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns. Three successful saves end the
spell. Three failed saves permanently petrify the
target. The successful or failed saves do not need to be consecutive; just keep track of the number of successful or failed saves until
you reach three of either type. ·7. Violet: The target is blinded on a failed save. It must make a Wisdom saving throw at the start of
your next turn. A successful save ends the blindness. A failed save causes the creature to be transported to
another plane specified by the DM and no longer blinded. (Typically, creatures not on their home plane are banished
home, while others are usually transported
to the Astral or Ethereal Planes.) ·8. Special: The target is hit by two rays. Roll twice more, and reroll on an 8.

have been dead no more than 100 years ago, must not have died of old age, and must not be undead. At this point, if the
creature's spirit is
willing and able to return, the target is resurrected with full hit points. · This spell also neutralizes poisons and common diseases
in the creature's body, but has no effect on magical diseases, curses, and similar effects; if these are not cured before
resurrection, they continue to be in effect when the creature returns to
life. · This spell can heal mortal wounds and restore lost body parts. · Returning from the dead is a painful experience. The
resurrected target takes a -4 penalty on subsequent attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks.
Each time the target finishes a long rest, the penalty is reduced by 1, stacking until the penalty is eliminated. · Using this spell
to revive a creature that has been dead for a year or more requires a great deal of effort on your part. You cannot
cast any spells until you finish a long rest, and you have
disadvantage on all attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

At the end of the spell's duration, the object or creature falls again.

The interior of the temple is an open space, with a statue or altar at one end. You decide whether the temple is lit, and whether
it is illuminated by bright or dim light. The temperature is pleasant, and the scent of incense fills the
air. When you cast this spell, you choose several types of creatures that the temple is hostile to. Choose one or more from the
following list: celestials, elementals, fey, fiends, or undead. If a creature of the chosen type attempts to enter the temple, it must
immediately make a Charisma saving throw. If it fails, it cannot enter the temple for 24 hours. Even if a creature is able to enter
the temple, magical forces hinder it; whenever it makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw in the temple, it must
roll an additional d4 and subtract that number from the result
of the d20. In addition, sensors created by divination spells cannot appear in the temple, and creatures in the temple cannot
be
located by divination spells. ·Finally, each time any creature within the temple regains hit points from a spell of 1st level or
higher, it regains additional hit points equal to
your Wisdom modifier (minimum 1). ·The temple is created by an opaque field of magical force that extends into the Ethereal
Plane, thus hindering any attempt to enter the temple through ethereal travel. Nothing can physically pass through the temple's
exterior. It is not dispelled by dispel magic, nor is it affected by an antimagic field. A disintegrate spell instantly
destroys the temple. ·If you cast this spell on the same location every day for a year, the spell's effects last forever.

· Two creatures you can see within range must make a Constitution saving
throw, or they have disadvantage if they are within 30 feet of each other. Each creature can voluntarily give up their saving
throw. If either creature succeeds, the spell has no effect. If both fail, they are magically linked together for the duration of the
spell, regardless of the distance between them. If one takes damage, the other takes an equal amount of damage. If one
regains hit points, the other regains an
equal amount of hit points. · If either of the bound creatures is reduced to 0 HP, the spell ends. When the spell ends on either
party, the spell ends on the other party as well.

V Verbal:
·A whistling whirlwind appears at a point visible on the ground
you designate. The whirlwind is a column 10 feet in radius and 30 feet high centered on the point you designate. Until the spell
ends, you can use your action to move up to 30 feet in any horizontal direction. The whirlwind draws in all objects no larger than
Medium that are fixed or not worn or held. ·A
creature that enters a whirlwind for the first time during its turn, or whose space is entered by a whirlwind (including the first
time a whirlwind appears), must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature that fails its saving throw takes 10d6 points of
bludgeoning damage, or half as much damage on a successful one. In addition, creatures of Large size or smaller that fail
their save must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be restrained by the whirlwind until the spell ends. When a creature
begins its turn restrained by the whirlwind, it is pushed upward 5 feet unless it reaches the apex. A restrained creature moves
with the
whirlwind, and falls when the spell ends unless it has another way to stay aloft. A restrained creature can use an action to make
a Strength or Dexterity check against your spell save DC. On a success, the creature is no longer restrained by the whirlwind
and is thrown 3d6×10
feet in a random direction.

draconic
magic to transform yourself, gaining various draconic traits. Until the spell ends, you gain the following benefits: √ Blindsight: You
gain blindsight out to 30 feet. Within this range, anything not behind full cover is visible to you, even if you are
blinded or in darkness. In addition, you can see invisible creatures unless they are hiding from you. √ Breath Weapon: When
you cast this spell, and on subsequent turns while the spell lasts, you can use a bonus action to exhale shimmering energy in a
60-foot cone. Each creature in the area
must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take 6d8 points of force damage, or half as much damage on a
successful save. √ Wings: Incorporeal wings sprout from your back, granting you a flying speed of 60 feet.

Spell Description:
· You draw moisture from every creature in a
30-foot cube centered on a point you designate within range. Each creature in the area must make a Constitution saving throw.
Constructs and undead are unaffected, but plants and water elementals have disadvantage on this saving throw. A creature takes
12d8 points of necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. ·
Nonmagical, nonliving plant life, such as trees and shrubs, in the area dies instantly.
Name: Abi-Dalzim's Horrid

V Verbal:
·You cast a spell to transform other creatures into beasts. Choose any
number of willing creatures within range, and transform each into a beast of challenge rating 4 or less and size Large or smaller. You
can use an action to transform the subject creatures into a different beast form as long as the spell lasts.
·The transformation lasts until the spell ends, or until the subject creature's hit points drop to 0 or dies. You can choose a
different form for each target. The target's game data is replaced with that of the selected beast, and it retains its original
alignment, as well as its Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. The target uses the hit points of the new form. When it
returns to its normal form, the target's hit points return to their pre-transformation values. If the target returns to its normal form
because its hit points drop to 0, the target's normal form takes any extra damage. As long as the extra damage is not enough to
reduce the normal form's hit points to 0, the target does not fall
unconscious. The subject creature can only use the actions of the new form and cannot speak or cast spells. ·The target's
equipment merges with its new form, and it cannot activate or wield
equipment or benefit from its equipment in any other way.

M Materials: Pinch of iron powder or filings
Duration:
·A 10-
foot-radius invisible sphere of antimagic energy surrounds you, isolating the area from the magical energies that permeate the
multiverse. Within the sphere:
spells cannot be cast; summoned creatures vanish without a trace; magic items lose their effects. The field moves centered
on you until the spell ends. ·Unless they originate from an artifact or the deity itself, all spells and magical effects are suppressed
within the field and cannot extend beyond it.
Spells cast within the field have their effects suppressed while the spell slots used are still expended. Suppressed magical effects
have no effect, but their durations are still calculated normally. ·Targeted Effects: Spells
and other magical effects that target creatures or objects (such as Magic Missile and Charm Person) have no effect on targets
within the field. Areas of Magic: Spells and other magical effects that create an area of effect (such as Fireball) do not extend into
the field. If the field overlaps with a magical effect, the effect is suppressed in the overlapping area. For example, when the field
overlaps with the flames of a wall of fire spell, the flames are suppressed in the overlapping area. If the
overlapping area is large enough, the wall of fire can be cut in half. Spells: Spells and other magical effects that affect creatures or
objects within the field are suppressed. Magic Items: The properties and powers of magic items are suppressed within the field.
For example, a +1 longsword is treated as a nonmagical longsword within the field. Magic weapons used to attack targets within
the field, or wielded by attackers within the field, have their properties and powers suppressed. If a magic weapon or
magical ammunition completely leaves the field (for example, if you fire an arrow or throw a javelin from within the field at a
target outside), the magic in it is restored the moment it leaves the field. Magic Travel: Teleportation or plane travel effects that begin
or end within the field do
not work. Portals to places, worlds, or planes, as well as portals to other dimensions (such as areas created by a rope trick) are
temporarily closed within the field. Creatures and Objects: Magically created or summoned
creatures and objects temporarily disappear within the field. A creature that disappears in this way reappears in the space it
occupied as soon as the field no longer covers it. Dispel Magic: Spells and other magical effects that create effects similar
to dispel magic have no effect on the field. In addition, antimagic
fields from different sources do not cancel each other out.
Name: Antimagic Field

to suit the size of the ruins. On a successful saving throw, it takes half as much damage, and is not knocked prone or buried.

Level:

area must be at least 120 feet on each side, and must not have any buildings or other structures standing on it. All creatures in
the area are lifted harmlessly
when the fortress rises. · The fortress has four square towers, each 20 feet long and 30 feet high, located at each corner of
the fortress. The towers are connected to each other by stone walls 80 feet long on each side, creating an enclosed area. Each
wall is 1 foot thick and made of stone slabs 10 feet wide and 20 feet high. Each slab is adjacent to two other slabs or to a slab
and a tower. You can place four stone
doors on the outer walls of the fortress. Within the enclosed area stands a small keep. The keep has a square base 50 feet long
and has three floors, each with a 10-foot-high ceiling. Each floor can be divided into as many rooms as you like, but each room
must be at least 5 feet long. Stone staircases connect the floors of the keep, which has walls 6 inches thick and interior rooms
with the type of doorways you choose (stone doors or open arches). The keep is furnished and decorated as you like, and it
can provide a nine-course feast for 100 people each day. Furniture, food, and other objects created by this spell that are
removed from the keep immediately turn to dust. You designate any creature when you cast this spell, and 100 invisible
servants serve as the fortress's staff, obeying any of their commands.
Each servant functions similarly to a creature created by the invisible servant spell. All walls, towers, and castles made of
stone are damaged. Each 10-foot-by-10-foot section of stone has an AC of 15 and 30 hit points per inch of thickness. It is immune
to poison and psychic damage. Reducing a section of stone to 0 hit points destroys it, and may
cause connected sections to buckle and collapse, at the discretion of your DM. After 7 days, or if you cast this spell again
elsewhere, the
fortress collapses harmlessly and sinks to the ground, leaving any creatures within safely above ground. Casting this
spell once every 7 days in the same location for a year
makes the fortress permanent.

Ritual:
·You and up to eight
willing creatures within range project your bodies into the Astral Plane (if you are already in the Astral Plane, the spell fails and is
consumed). Your original body is rendered unconscious and stasis-incapable, requiring no air or food and not aging. ·Your astral
body retains its original form almost perfectly, retaining your
original game data and belongings. The main difference between your astral body and your physical body is a silver cord that
extends back from between your shoulder blades. This visible cord, just one foot long, connects your astral body to your physical
body. As long as the cord remains intact, you can always find your way back to your physical world. Only effects that specifically
sever the cord can sever it. Severing the cord separates your soul from your physical body and kills
you. Your astral body can travel freely in the Astral Plane and can pass through portals in the Astral Plane to other planes. If you
arrive on a new plane or return to the plane you were on when you cast the spell, your physical body and items are transported
along the cord, allowing you to arrive on the new plane in your physical form. Your astral body is a separate entity. Damage or
effects inflicted on your
astral body do not affect your physical body, nor do they persist when you return to your physical body. You can use an action to
dismiss the spell, ending its
effects on you and your companions. When the spell ends, the affected creature returns to its original body and awakens. · You or
one of your companions may end the spell's effects prematurely. A successful Dispel Magic cast on a creature's true or astral body
ends the creature's projection. If a creature's true or astral body is reduced to 0 hit points, the creature's own projection ends. If the
cord remains
connected when the spell ends, the creature is pulled back to its original body and out of stasis. · If you are sent back to your true
body before the spell ends, your companion is left in the astral plane and can only return on his
own (usually by reducing his hit points to 0).

you cast this spell, you choose a form of prison from the following: Burial: The target is buried deep in the
ground, in a spherical field of magical force just large enough to envelop the target. Nothing can pass through
the field, and no creature can enter or leave the field by teleportation or plane travel. (Special material: a small
mithril ball) Chaining: Heavy chains are firmly rooted in the earth, binding the target to the spot. The target is
bound until the spell ends, during which time it cannot move or be moved in any way.
(Special material: a length of fine precious metal chain) Hedged Prison: This spell transports the target to a
small demiplane that is isolated from teleportation and plane travel. The demiplane can be a maze, a cell,
a
tower, or any other claustrophobic building or area of your choice. (Special material: a jade miniature prison)
Minimus Containment: The target is shrunk to 1 inch tall and imprisoned in a
gemstone or similar object. Light can pass through the gemstone normally (allowing the target to see out and
other creatures to see in), but nothing else can enter or leave it, not even by teleportation or plane travel. The
gemstone cannot be cut or
broken while the spell remains in effect. (Special material: a large transparent gemstone such as corundum,
diamond, or ruby) Slumber: The target falls into a coma and cannot be awakened. (Special material: a rare
soporific herb) End Spell: For either version of the spell, you can set a condition during the casting that causes
the spell to end and release the target. This condition can be as specific or complex
as you wish, but the DM must approve the condition as reasonable and achievable.
This condition can be based on a creature's name, identity, or divine status, but must otherwise be based on
observable behavior or characteristics, not on intangibles such as level, class, or hit points. · The spell Dispel
Magic can end this spell, but only when cast using a 9th-level spell slot and targeting the prison or the special
substance that creates the prison effect. · You can create only one
prison at a time using the same special substance. If you cast the spell again using the same special substance,
the previously imprisoned creature
is immediately freed from its imprisonment.

Level:
· You can transform up to 10 visible creatures of your choice
within range. Involuntary targets must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw to resist the transformation. An
involuntary shapechanger automatically succeeds on this save. ·
Each target gains the same or a different beast of your choice. The new form can be any beast you have
seen with a challenge rating less than or equal to the target's challenge rating (if the target has no challenge
rating, the upper limit is half the target's challenge rating). The targets' game statistics, including mental
attribute scores, are replaced with those of the beast you chose, but they retain their health points, alignment, and personality.

· Each target gains temporary hit points equal to the new form's hit points. These temporary hit points can't be replaced with temporary hit
points from another source. The creature reverts to its original form when it loses these temporary hit points or dies. If the spell ends before
this, the temporary hit points are lost and the creature
reverts to its original form. · The creature's actions are limited by the characteristics of its new form. It can't speak, cast spells, or do anything
else that requires
the use of hands or speech. · The target's equipment merges with the new form, and the target creature can't activate, use, wield, or
otherwise benefit from its equipment.

Spell Description:
· Select four different locations you can see within range and cause
flaming meteors to plummet to the ground above them. The meteors from the explosion affect a spherical area with a radius of 40 feet
around the designated point. The area effect spreads around corners. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw. A
creature that fails the saving throw takes 20d6 points of fire damage and 20d6 points of bludgeoning damage, while a successful saving throw
takes half as
much damage. In addition, a creature in the area of multiple explosions at the same time is still only affected once. · This spell damages
objects in the area and ignites any flammable
objects that are not worn or carried.
Name: Meteor Swarm

Name: Protection
column23:
· A shimmering, multicolored plane of
light forms an opaque wall. The wall is perpendicular to the ground and is up to 90 feet long, 30 feet high, and 1 inch thick, with its origin at a
point you can see within range. You can also shape the wall into a sphere up to 30 feet in diameter, centered at a point you can see within
range. The wall remains in place for the duration of the spell. If positioning the wall so that it passes through a space occupied by a creature,
the spell fails and your action and spell slot are wasted. · The wall extends 100 feet of bright light, plus an additional 100 feet of dim light.
You and the creature you specify when casting this spell can pass
through or remain near the wall without taking damage. If another creature that can see the wall moves within 20 feet of it or starts its turn
there, that creature must make a Constitution saving throw or be blinded for 1 minute. The wall is made up of seven layers, each with a
different color. A creature attempting to enter or pass through the wall passes through each of the layers of light
it passes through. It must make a Dexterity saving throw for each layer it passes through, or be affected by the properties of the layers
listed below. The wall can be destroyed, but it must pass through each layer one at a time, from red to purple.
Once a layer is destroyed, it remains destroyed for the duration of the spell. Antimagic Field has no effect on the wall, and Dispel Magic
works only on purple walls. 1. Red: Creature takes 10d6 points of fire damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a
successful one. Nonmagical ranged attacks cannot
pass through the wall while this layer is present. The light layer is destroyed if it takes at least 25 points of cold damage. ·2. Orange: The
creature takes 10d6 points of acid damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much
damage on a successful one. While this light layer exists, magical ranged attacks cannot penetrate the wall. The light layer is destroyed by
strong winds. ·3. Yellow: The creature takes 10d6 points of lightning damage
on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one. The light layer is destroyed if it takes at least 60 points of force
damage. ·4. Green: The
creature takes 10d6 points of poison damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one. The light layer is
destroyed by the spell Passwall, or any spell of equal or higher level that opens an opening in a solid surface. ·5.
Blue: The creature takes 10d6 points of cold damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one. The light layer
is destroyed if it
takes at least 25 points of fire damage. ·6. Indigo: The creature is restrained on a failed saving throw. At the end of each of its turns, it makes
a Constitution saving throw. After three successful saves, the spell ends. After three failed saves, the target is permanently petrified. Successful or failed saves do not need 
Until you reach three of either type. Spells cannot pass through this layer of light while it exists. The layer is destroyed by daylight or
other bright light from a spell of equal or higher level. 7. Violet:
The creature is blinded on a failed save. It must make a Wisdom saving throw at the start of your next turn. On a successful save,
the blindness ends. On a failed save, the creature is transported to another plane designated by the DM and is no longer blinded.
(Typically, creatures not on their home plane are banished to their home plane, while others are usually transported to the Astral or
Ethereal Planes.) This layer of light is destroyed by dispel magic or other similar spells of equal or higher level that end spells.

Duration:
· You unleash the power of your mind, bombarding the minds of up to 10
visible creatures of your choice within range. Creatures with an Intelligence score of 2 or lower
are unaffected. · Each target must make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 14d6 psychic damage and
is stunned. On a successful save, the target takes half damage and is not stunned. If a headed target is killed by
this damage, its head explodes. · A stunned creature can remake its Intelligence saving throw at the end of each of its turns. On
a successful save, the stunning effect ends.

Spell Description:
· You
create a 20-foot-radius spherical field of destructive force with a point visible to you within range as its source. For the duration of the
spell, the spherical field and the space within 100 feet of it are treated as difficult terrain, and unworn and uncarried nonmagical
objects completely within the field are destroyed. ·When the field appears or at the start of each of your turns, unworn objects within
100 feet of it are pulled straight toward the center of the field and come to
rest in the unoccupied space nearest to the center. When a creature starts its turn within 100 feet of the force, it must make a
Strength saving throw or be pulled straight toward the center of the force and come to rest in the nearest unoccupied space. A
creature that enters the force for the first time this turn or starts its turn within it takes 5d10 points of force damage and is restrained
until it leaves the force's range. If the force is in midair, restrained creatures are suspended in the force. A creature can use its action
to make a Strength check against your spell save DC and, if successful, free itself or another creature within its reach from the
restraints. If a creature's hit points are reduced to 0 by this spell, it and any nonmagical objects it carries are destroyed.

Spell Name: worn on the head while casting the spell
School:
· You polymorph into another
creature for the duration of the spell. Your new form can be any creature with a challenge rating equal to or less than your level. The
creature can't be a construct or undead, and you must have seen it before at least once. You become a normal member of that
creature, without any class levels or spellcasting features. · Your game data is replaced by
the target creature's statistics, but your alignment, as well as your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores, remain unchanged.
You also retain all your proficiency with skills and saving throws, and gain the target creature's proficiency with skills and saving
throws. If the target creature and you both have a proficiency, and the target creature has a higher proficiency bonus with that skill
than you do, you use the higher proficiency bonus instead of your own for that skill.
You can’t use your new form’s legendary actions or lair actions. Your hit points and hit dice become the same as your new form.
When you revert to your original form, your hit points return to what they were before the transformation. If you revert because your
hit points dropped below 0, your normal form takes all the extra damage. You don’t
fall unconscious as long as the damage isn’t enough to reduce your normal hit points to 0. You still gain the benefits of your class
features, racial traits, and other traits, as long as your new form is physically able to do them. You can’t use any special senses you
had before (such as darkvision) unless your new form has them. If the creature you’re
transformed into can’t normally speak, you can’t speak. When you transform, you can choose to have your gear fall to the ground,
merge with your new form, or remain on. Gear that remains on still functions normally. The DM should decide whether you can keep
each piece of gear on in your new form, based on the shape and size of your new form. Your equipment does not change shape or
size to accommodate your new form, and equipment that cannot be worn in your new
form must be dropped to the ground or integrated into your new form. Equipment integrated into the new form has no effect. ·
During the spell's duration, you can use your action to change into another form. The rules and restrictions of reshaping are the
same as the first time, with one exception: if the new form has more hit points than your current form, your hit points remain unchanged.

Spell Description:
·A churning cloud spreads out from a point you
can see to a 360-foot-radius area, filling the area with lightning, thunder, and howling winds. All creatures beneath the cloud (within 5,000 feet
of the cloud) must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature that fails the save takes 2d6 points of thunder damage and becomes deafened
for 5 minutes. ·Each round you maintain concentration on
this spell, the storm produces a new effect on your turn: ·Round 2: Acid rain falls from the cloud. All
creatures and objects below the cloud take 1d6 points of acid damage. ·Round 3: Rounds: You call down six bolts of
lightning from the cloud to strike six creatures or objects of your choice beneath the cloud. Each creature or object can be struck only once. A
creature struck must make a Dexterity saving throw or take 10d6 points of lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a
successful one. Round 4: Hail pours
down from the cloud. All creatures beneath the cloud take 2d6 points of bludgeoning damage. Rounds 5-10: Strong winds
and sleet lash the area beneath the cloud, turning it into difficult terrain and heavily obscuring it. All creatures within the area take 1d6 points
of frost damage. Ranged weapon attacks are unavailable in the area. The strong winds and heavy rain within the area severely interfere with
maintaining spell concentration. In addition, strong winds (20 to 50 miles per hour) in the area automatically disperse any magical or nonmagical
smoke and other similar phenomena within the area.
Name: Storm of Vengeance

Material Content:
An hourglass filled with diamond dust, worth at least 5,000 gp, is consumed
when the spell is cast
Spell Description:
· You choose a target within range and subject its physical form to rapid aging. The target must make a
Constitution saving throw and takes 12d10 points of necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If it fails
its saving throw, the target also rapidly ages to the point where it is only thirty days away from death by old age. At this age, the target suffers
disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws, and its walking speed is halved. Only a wish or Greater Restoration cast in a
ninth-level spell slot can negate these effects and restore the target to its original age.
Name: Timeravaged

Spell Description:
· You
cause time to temporarily stop for all creatures in the world except you. You perform this action for 1d4+1 turns at a time, during which time
stands still for other creatures, but you can move and use actions as normal. · During the spell's duration, if one of your actions or any effect
you create affects any creature other
than you, or affects an object worn or carried by another creature, the spell ends immediately. Additionally, if you move more than 1000 feet
from the casting location after casting the spell, the spell ends as a result.
Name: Time Stop

· You select a creature or object you can see within range and transform it. You can change the target creature into a different
creature, into an object, or into a creature (the object must not be worn or carried by any creature). The transformation lasts until the spell's
duration ends, or until the target's hit points drop to 0 or the target dies. If you maintain concentration on the spell for the duration, the
transformation lasts permanently. ·This spell has no effect on transformed creatures or targets with 0 hit points. A creature that does not wish
to be transformed can make a Wisdom saving throw. If the saving throw succeeds, it is not affected by
the spell. Creature to Creature: If you polymorph a creature into another creature, its new form can be any species of your choice with a
challenge rating equal to or lower
than the subject's challenge rating (or its character level if the subject has no challenge rating). The subject's game data (including mental
ability scores) is replaced by the new form's data, but its alignment and personality remain unchanged.

you. ·Creature to Object: If you polymorph a creature into an object, it changes into its new form along with everything it wears
and carries. The subject's statistics become the same as the object's, and after the spell ends and the subject returns to its
original form, it will not remember anything that happened while it was an object.

School:
·You touch a dead creature to bring it back to life. The
creature must have died less than 200 years ago, and the cause of death cannot be old age. If the creature's soul
is willing and able to return to its body, it will be resurrected with full hit points. ·This spell can heal all fatal wounds, neutralize
all poisons and diseases, and remove all
curses that it suffered in life. This spell can even restore damaged or lost organs and limbs. If the subject creature's body no
longer exists, this spell can even create a new body for it. To do this, you must call out the creature's name, and the creature will
appear in an unoccupied space within 10 feet of the
point you specify.

Name: Player's Handbook

V Verbal:
·Wish is the most powerful spell a mortal can cast.
You can manipulate the foundations of reality simply by speaking your wish aloud. ·The most basic use of this spell is to imitate
any spell of 8th level or lower. You do not need to meet any prerequisites of
the target spell (including expensive material components) for the
spell to work. ·In addition, you can also choose to create one of the following effects: √You create an object worth no more than
25,000 gp. The object cannot be a magic item. The longest dimension of the
object cannot exceed 300 feet, and it appears on the ground at the time of the spell
in an unoccupied space you can see. √You restore up to twenty creatures you can see
to their full hit points and end all effects described in Greater Restoration on them. √ You
make up to ten creatures you can see resistant to a type of damage you specify √ You make up to ten creatures you can see
immune to a spell or other magical effect for
eight hours. For example, you can make yourself and all your companions immune to a lich's drain life. √ You alter an event that
just happened. Reroll any die roll from the previous round (including the one you made the previous round) and cause reality to
change according to your new roll. For example, a wish spell can undo an opponent's successful save, a foe's critical hit, or an
ally's failed save.
You can force the reroll to have advantage or disadvantage, and you can choose whether to use the rerolled result or the
original result. · You may be able to achieve other results in addition to the example effects listed above. You can explain your
wish in detail to the DM, who will make the decision. However, the larger your wish, the greater the chance of error. The spell
may fail, or it may partially achieve the result you want, or you may suffer unexpected results if you word your wish improperly.
For example, wishing for the death of a villain might transport you to a time many years later when that
person is dead, effectively leaving the game. Also, wishing for a legendary magic item or artifact might instantly transport
you to the object's current owner. Casting this spell for any purpose other than to mimic another spell places a heavy burden on
you. While burdened, you take damage (1d10 points of necrotic damage per level of the spell you cast) each time you cast a spell
until you finish a long rest. You can't mitigate or prevent this damage in any way, and your Strength score drops to 3 in 2d4 days
(unless it's already 3 or lower). During this time, for every full day you spend resting (not doing any strenuous work), the number of
days it takes to recover decreases by 2. Finally, if you take on this burden, you have a 33% chance of never being able to cast Wish again.
